description: Analytical techniques applied to engineering problems in transport phenomena, process dynamics and control, and thermodynamics.

name: Applied Engineering Mathematics II
description: Focuses on biomedical system identification. Includes fundamental techniques of model building and testing such as formulation, solution of governing equations, sensitivity theory, identifiability theory, and uncertainty analysis.
restriction: Graduate students only.

name: Introduction to Computational Biology
description: The use of theories and methods based on computer science, mathematics, and physics in molecular biology and biochemistry. Basics in biomolecular modeling. Analysis of sequence and structural data of biomolecules. Analysis of biomolecular functions.
restriction: Graduate students only.

name: Dynamic Systems in Biology and Medicine
description: Introduces principles of system theory to analyze biological, biochemical, physiological, and bioengineering systems. Analytical and computational tools are used to model and analyze dynamic systems such as population, neuronal and heart dynamics, biochemical and physiological systems, oxygen diffusion and similar.
restriction: Graduate students only.

name: Neuroimaging Data Analysis
description: Knowledge and understanding of recent techniques for the analysis of healthy and pathological structure and function in neuroimaging data.
restriction: Graduate students only.

name: Spectroscopy and Imaging of Biological Systems
description: Principles of spectroscopy; absorption; molecular orbitals; multiphoton transitions; Jablonski diagram; fluorescence anisotropy; fluorescence decay; quenching; FRET; excited state reactions; solvent relaxations; instruments; microscopy: wide field, LSM, TPE; fluorescent probes, fluctuations spectroscopy; optical resolution and super-resolution; CARS and SHG microscopy.
restriction: Graduate students only.

name: Introduction to Clinical Medicine for Biomedical Engineering
description: An introduction to clinical medicine for graduate students in biomedical engineering. Lectures and rotations through Nephology, Gastroenterology, Pulmonary & Critical Care Cardiology.
restriction: Biomedical Engineering graduate students only.

name: Biospectroscopy
description: Principles of optical spectroscopy for biomedical engineering. Will focus on optical spectroscopy of biological relevant molecules, spectroscopy in cells and tissue. Spectroscopy techniques based on fluorescence.
restriction: Graduate students only.

name: Engineering Medical Optics
description: Principles of optics and photonics, integration of optical components into systems and devices, and analysis of physiologic signals obtained from Biophotonics measurements.
restriction: Graduate students only.

name: Critical Thinking in Biophotonics
description: Critical thematic review of current research papers in the field of Biophotonics.
repeatability: May be taken for credit 2 times.
restriction: Graduate students only.

name: Microfluids and Lab-On-A-Chip
description: Introduction to microfluidics and state-of-the-art micro Total Analysis Systems (uTAS). Lab-on-a-Chip for biomolecular assays with device design principles for microscale sample preparation, flow transport, biolmolecular manipulation, separation and detection, and the technologies for integrating these devices into microsystems.
restriction: Graduate students only.

name: Biomedical Microdevices
description: In-depth review of microfabricated devices designed for biological and medical applications. Studies of the design, implementation, manufacturing, and marketing of commercial and research bio-medical devices.
restriction: Graduate students only.

name: Microimplants
description: Essential concepts of biomedical implants at the micro scale. Design, fabrication, and applications of several microimplantable devices including cochlear, retinal, neural, and muscular implants.
restriction: Graduate students only.

name: Nanomedicine
description: Covers the use of inorganic nanocrystals and nanocarriers for molecular detection of human disease and targeted drug delivery. Techniques for synthesis and bioconjugation, molecular targeting, adhesion dynamics, and unique physical properties of nanomaterials.
restriction: Graduate students only.

name: Auditory Science and Technology
description: Advanced topics in auditory science and technology from cochlear mechanics to cochlear implants.
repeatability: May be repeated for credit unlimited times.
restriction: Graduate students only.

name: Critical Thinking and Writing
description: Critical thinking and writing are essential ingredients for success in scientific research. Examines examples from the scientific literature to extract principles of good scientific reasoning, experimental design, and writing.
restriction: Graduate students only.

name: Special Topics in Biomedical Engineering
description: Studies in selected areas of Biomedical Engineering. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.

name: Master of Science Thesis Research
description: Individual research or investigation conducted in the pursuit of preparing and completing the thesis required for the M.S. in Engineering.
repeatability: May be repeated for credit unlimited times.
restriction: Graduate students only.

name: Doctor of Philosophy Dissertation Research
description: Individual research or investigation conducted in the pursuit of preparing and completing the dissertation required for the Ph.D. in Engineering.
repeatability: May be repeated for credit unlimited times.

name: Seminars in Biomedical Engineering
description: Presentation of advanced topics and reports of current research efforts in biomedical engineering. Designed for graduate students in the Biomedical Engineering program.
repeatability: May be repeated for credit unlimited times.

name: Individual Research
description: Individual research or investigation under the direction of an individual faculty.
repeatability: May be repeated for credit unlimited times.

name: Introduction to Chicano/Latino Studies I
description: An introduction to the study of the historical foundations of the Chicano/Latino experience.  Addresses such topics as empire, migration, immigrant settlement, economic integration, race, gender, and the formation of group identities.

name: Introduction to Chicano/Latino Studies II
description: Provides an introduction to the arts, literature, and culture of Chicano/Latino communities. Analyzes representations of and cultural production in Chicano/Latino communities through such media as folklore, literature, art, film, architecture, dance theatre, performance, music, poetry, mass media, and language.

name: Introduction to Chicano/Latino Studies III
description: Examines contemporary public policy issues in Chicano/Latino communities. Each offering addresses at least three of the following themes: migration, immigrant incorporation, identity construction, language policy, health policy, politics, sexuality, gender, labor, class, and education.  Course may be offered online.

name: Introduction to Race and Ethnicity in Political Science
description: Examines major theories that attempt to explain the roles of race and ethnicity in U.S. politics.  Course may be offered online.

name: Ethnic and Immigrant America
description: Focusing on Asian, Latino, and Black immigrant groups, examines the second generation's experience of straddling two cultures and growing up American. Covers topics such as assimilation, bilingualism, race relations, education, bicultural conflicts, interracial marriage, and multiracial identities.

name: Anthropology of Food
description: Examines how food communicates ideas about ethnocentrism, disgust, privilege, gender, race, labor, social identities and hierarchies, globalization, power, and the "Western diet" and its health consequences.

name: Lower-Division Special Topics in Chicano/Latino Studies
description: Studies in selected areas of Chicano/Latino Studies. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.

name: Latina/o Childhoods: Comparative Approaches to the Study of Children and Youth
description: Students in this seminar compare the experiences of Latina/o children to other young people in the U.S. and around the world, analyzing the historical, political, economic, and sociocultural factors that have differently structured the life stage we understand as “childhood.”.
restriction: Campuswide Honors Program students only.

name: Research in the Latino Community
description: Students engage in firsthand research in the local Orange County environment. Students identify a research problem, conduct a literature review, develop questions and/or hypotheses, appropriate methods, and write a proposal.
prerequisite: Two courses from CHC/LAT 61 or CHC/LAT 62 or CHC/LAT 63 and two courses from CHC/LAT 110-189
restriction: Chicano/Latino Studies majors have first consideration for enrollment.

name: Supervised Research for Chicano/Latino Studies Majors
description: Students who have designed a research project & begun collecting data in CHC/LAT 101 will continue to collect/analyze data for their research projects. By end of the course, students will be prepared to write up their findings in CHC/LAT 102W.
restriction: Chicano/Latino Studies majors only.

name: Chicano/Latino Research Seminar
description: Taught as a writing and research seminar in Chicano/Latino Studies.  Student develops own project; engages in peer editing; drafts, writes, and presents paper at Spring research conference.  Prior course work in Chicano/Latino Studies helpful, i.e., CHC/LAT 61, 62, 63.
restriction: Upper-division students only. Chicano/Latino Studies Majors only.

name: Topics in Chicano Literature and Culture
description: Studies in selected areas of Chicano/Latino Studies. Topics addressed vary each quarter. Taught in English.
repeatability: May be taken for credit 4 times as topics vary.

name: Film Media and the Latino Community
description: Uses film as a resource for understanding contemporary issues and problems facing the Chicano/Latino community.  (Does not study cinema as a genre.).

name: Latino Music:  A View of Its Diversity and Strength
description: A survey of the music of the many Latin cultures of the Americas including Mexico, Central and South America, as well as the Caribbean and of those many Latin cultures which thrive and survive in the United States.

name: Reading Images Culturally
description: Provides analytical tools necessary to undertake research on visual representations. Images, as cultural productions, are steeped in the values, ideologies, and taken-for-granted beliefs of the culture which produced them. Of concern are representations of race, identity, gender, and the "Other.".

name: Anthropology of Food
description: Examines how food communicates ideas about ethnocentrism, disgust, privilege, gender, race, labor, social identities and hierarchies, globalization, power, and the "Western diet" and its health consequences.

name: Peoples and Cultures of Latin America
description: Surveys the prehistory of Latin America and its indigenous cultures, emphasizing the impact of colonial rule, capitalism, and twentieth-century transformations.  Emphasis on communities from several countries. In some years, emphasis on comparisons between the Latin American and Caribbean experiences.

name: Latina/Latino Pop:  Latina/Latino Popular Culture
description: With a focus on the politics of language and space/place, prepares students to critically analyze sites of Latina/Latino popular culture including: music, film, performance, sports, media, and varied subcultures.
restriction: Chicano/Latino Studies majors have first consideration for enrollment.

name: Immigration, Nation, and Media
description: Examines media shapes and reflects public opinion on immigration and its representation of immigrants, citizens, and ideas about the nation, and who belongs and who is a potential threat; as well as the relationship between scholars and journalists.

name: Special Topics in Literature, Arts, Media, Culture
description: Studies in selected areas of Chicano/Latino Studies. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.
restriction: Chicano/Latino Studies majors have first consideration for enrollment.

name: Introduction to Cuba: History, Culture, and Society
description: Introduction to Cuban history, culture, and society using social science texts, visual and musical materials. Examines major historical moments including the historical relationship between the United States and explores evolution of Cuban music from the earliest times to present.

name: Chicana/Chicano History: Pre-Colonial to 1900
description: Examines social history of the southwest region from antiquity to 1900. Discusses major questions, theory and research methods pertinent to Chicanas/Chicanos. Themes include: indigenous empires, conquest, colonialism, social stratification, ideology, marriage, sexuality, industrial capitalism, accommodation and resistance.

name: Chicana/Chicano History: Twentieth Century
description: Examines social history of the Southwest with emphasis on Mexican-origin people. Discusses major questions, theory and research methods pertinent to Chicana/Chicano history. Themes explored include: immigration, xenophobia, class struggle, leadership, generational cohorts, unionization, education, barrioization, ethnicity, patriarchy, sexuality.

name: Twentieth-Century Mexico
description: Examines the history of contemporary Mexico beginning with the Mexican Revolution and concluding with the present administration. Social, economic, and political effects of the Revolution; formation of a "one-party democracy"; economic transformation of the nation; the present crisis.

name: U
description: Focuses on aspects of literature, art, cultural production, and history of the multifaceted Latino cultures that have developed within the United States.  Focuses on one group, such as Caribbean Americans, Chicanos, Central Americans, or a comparative perspective of several groups.

name: Latinas in the Twentieth Century U
description: Latinas in the U.S. from 1900 to present, offering a diversity of their cultures, regional histories, sexualities, generations, and classes.

name: Special Topics in Chicano/Latino History
description: Studies in selected areas of Chicano/Latino History. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.
restriction: Chicano/Latino majors only.

name: Latina/Latino Queer Sexualities
description: Introduces students to the notion of "queer" in relation to Chicanas/Chicanos and Latinas/Latinos and provides students with theoretical frameworks to explore the shifting categories of sexuality, gender, Chicano, Latino within the scholarship areas of Chicana/Chicano and Latina/Latino Studies.
restriction: Chicano/Latino Studies majors have first consideration for enrollment.

name: Latinos and the Law
description: Examines a range of theoretical, empirical, and policy approaches to legal issues affecting the Latino population, with emphasis on California. Discusses topics concerning the purpose of law, the creation of law, and the enforcement of law.

name: Comparative Minority Politics
description: Examines the political experiences of Blacks, Latinos, and Asian Americans in the United States from roughly 1950 to the present. Focuses on how each group has pursued political empowerment via both conventional political channels and social movements.

name: Racial and Ethnic Relations in the United States
description: Examines central questions and issues in the field of race and ethnicity; the emergence, maintenance, and consequences of the ethnic and racial stratification system in the United States; the future of racial and ethnic relations; and relevant public policy issues.
restriction: Sociology majors have first consideration for enrollment.

name: Racial and Ethnic Relations in the United States
description: Examines central questions and issues in the field of race and ethnicity; the emergence, maintenance, and consequences of the ethnic and racial stratification system in the United States; the future of racial and ethnic relations; and relevant public policy issues.
prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement
restriction: Chicano/Latino Studies and Sociology majors have first consideration for enrollment.

prereq.value: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement

name: U
description: Explores political, economic, social, and cultural ties that bind Latin America to the United States. Focuses on U.S. intervention and Latin American response from early nineteenth century to present day. Case studies include Mexico, Guatemala, Cuba, Chile, and Central America.

name: Latinos in U
description: Comparing the political issues facing Latino groups by examining their migration histories, voting behavior, nonelectoral participation, and policy issues.  Latino issues are examined on the national, state, and local levels, including formal representation, immigration, affirmative action, and language policy.

name: Latin American Politics
description: Introduces the main concepts and theoretical approaches underlying the study of Latin American politics, examines recent political dynamics, and explores the challenges the region faces in the twenty-first century and how countries will attempt to address them.
restriction: Political Science majors, Chicano/Latino Studies majors, and International Studies majors have first consideration for enrollment.

name: Revolution in Latin America
description: Presents a comparative analysis of the causes, development, and consequences of selected revolutionary movements, focusing on outbreaks in Mexico, Bolivia, Cuba, Chile, Nicaragua, and Grenada.  Explores topics of state formation, economic nationalism, social justice, ethnicity, and role of international affairs.

name: Race, Ethnicity, and Social Control
description: Provides a historical and sociological survey of racial and ethnic group relations in contexts of crime control, emphasizing the roles of racial ideology, structural racism, and social movements in shaping these dynamic relations, and their significance to American liberal democracy.

name: Cross-Cultural Research on Urban Gangs
description: Taking an urban policy approach, examines the background and contemporary traditions of gangs in several ethnic groups including African-, Asian-, and Mexican-Americans. Cross-cultural exploration of the varied facets of gang life. The major social-control institutions affecting them.
restriction: Criminology, Law and Society, Social Ecology, and Chicano/Latino Studies majors have first consideration for enrollment.

name: Latino Metropolis
description: Explores the processes of Latino urbanization in the United States and the spatialization of Latino identities, particularly in the context of Southern California with selected comparisons drawing from other cities.

name: Culture Change and the Mexican People
description: Reviews culture contact and colonization, innovation diffusion, acculturation, assimilation, culture conflict and marginality, modernization, urbanization, legal transformations. Mexico and the Southwestern U.S. are reviewed through several centuries to better appreciate the indigenous base of the Mexican people.

name: Chicano/Latinos and Labor
description: Explores theories that explain the occupational pathways and workplace experiences of Latinos in various work sectors. Investigates jobs such as migrant labor, child street vendors, Latina/Latino professionals, and Latinos migrating to the U.S. South that work in poultry processing plants.
prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement

prereq.value: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement

name: Cuban Society and Revolution
description: Explores the causes, development, and legacy of the 1959 Revolution. Themes include economic dependency, democracy, race, gender, culture, and the always volatile relations between Cuba and the United States.

name: Feminisms of Color
description: Surveys the development of Chicana feminist thought and practice.  Focuses on historical contemporary writings by and about Chicana feminists.  Draws from interdisciplinary scholarship in order to survey the diversity of Chicana feminisms.

name: Feminisms of Color
description: Surveys the development of Chicana feminist thought and practice.  Focuses on historical contemporary writings by and about Chicana feminists.  Draws from interdisciplinary scholarship in order to survey the diversity of Chicana feminisms.
prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement

prereq.value: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement

name: Special Topics in Society, Labor, Politics, Law, Gender, Race, Ethnicity
description: Studies in selected areas of Chicano/Latino Studies. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.
restriction: Chicano/Latino majors only.

name: Perspectives on the U
description: Economic aspects of the historical development of the United States-Mexican border.  The current economic situation in the Southwest and border areas as it affects both Mexico and the Latino/Chicano population is also examined.

name: Transnational Migration
description: Examines the movement of people across national borders, governmentality and the role of state practices to control populations, and issues of citizenship, belonging, and identity. Examples are drawn from the United States, Europe, Latin America, Asia, and Africa.

name: Urban America
description: Students examine the historical, social, political, and economic factors that contributed to the construction of the American urban context, one that is poverty concentrated and racially/ethnically segregated. Students also critically assess the consequence of growing up in America's urban neighborhoods.

name: U
description: Examines selected immigration policy debates since the nineteenth century, rationale and consequences of immigration law since 1965, problems of administration, implementation and enforcement, impact of immigration policy on foreign relations, and contemporary debate regarding the future of U.S. policy.

name: Chicano Movement
description: Explores the history of Mexicans in the U.S. with particular attention paid to their integration into the U.S. capitalist economy.  Examines this economic history and the Chicano movement, "El Movimiento," within the wide context of socio-economic change.
restriction: Chicano/Latino Studies, Urban Studies, and Social Ecology majors have first consideration for enrollment.

name: Latinos in a Global Society
description: Examines interconnections between diverse Latino groups in the U.S. and the effects of globalization on their social, cultural, and political realities. Topics include immigration, demographics, socioeconomic differentiation, familial relations, political protest/resistance, law and policy, and links to "homeland" issues.

name: Chicano/Latino Social Psychology
description: Examines theories, research, and major issues of relevance to understanding social psychological processes in Chicano/Latino populations. Topics include social development, cultural orientations, gender and sexuality, close relationships, happiness and well-being, stereotyping, prejudice and discrimination, and mental and physical health.
prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement
restriction: Psychology and Social Behavior, Social Ecology, and Chicano/Latino Studies majors have first consideration for enrollment.

prereq.value: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement

name: Special Topics in Globalization, Transnationalism, Immigration, U
description: Studies in selected areas of Chicano/Latino Studies. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.

name: Chicano/Latino Families
description: Introduction to the research, literature, and issues surrounding the topic of Chicano/Latino families including cultural history, contemporary issues, organization of family, traditions, lifestyles, values, beliefs, generational differences, gender issues, ethnic identity, evolution of demographic patterns, current economic and political standings.

name: Chicano/Latino Psychology
description: Examines research and literature investigating Chicano/Latino ethnicity as a variable influencing behavior.  Explores mental health needs and issues of Chicano/Latinos and discusses competent, sensitive methods of mental health service delivery.

name: Race, Gender, and Science
description: Perfect for pre-health, science and social science majors wanting to appreciate how science and society interact. Race and gender as biological and socio-cultural constructs are examined. Questions explored: What is disease? What is science? What are social and biological differences.

name: Culture and Close Relationships
description: Examines cultural influences on close relationship processes including attraction, love, friendship, family, social support, and significance of close relationships for health and well-being. National and ethnic sources of cultural variation examined include Latin America, Asia, Africa, and the Middle East.
restriction: Psychology and Social Behavior, Social Ecology, and Chicano/Latino Studies majors have first consideration for enrollment.

name: Culture and Close Relationships
description: Examines cultural influences on close relationship processes including attraction, love, friendship, family, social support, and significance of close relationships for health and well-being. National and ethnic sources of cultural variation examined include Latin America, Asia, Africa, and the Middle East.
prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement
restriction: Psychology and Social Behavior, Social Ecology, and Chicano/Latino Studies majors have first consideration for enrollment.

prereq.value: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement

name: Health and the Latino Paradox
description: Examines research and theories concerning the physical and mental health of U.S. Latino populations. Contemporary accounts, health care implications, and new directions for understanding sources of risks and resilience for health in Latino populations are evaluated and discussed.
prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement
restriction: Psychology and Social Behavior, Social Ecology, and Chicano/Latino Studies majors have first consideration for enrollment.

prereq.value: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement

name: Medical Anthropology
description: Introduces students to cross-cultural perspectives and critical theories in anthropological studies of medicine. Special attention is given to diverse ways of understanding bodies, illnesses, and therapeutic practices in our changing world.  Course may be offered online.

name: Special Topics in Health, Medicine, and Psychosocial Dynamics
description: Studies in selected areas of Chicano/Latino Studies. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.
restriction: Chicano/Latino Studies majors have first consideration for enrollment.

name: Multicultural Education in K-12 Schools
description: Provides a theoretical and empirical overview of educational issues affecting low-income immigrant and U.S.-born minority student populations in an increasingly diverse and changing society.

name: Special Topics in Educational Policy and Issues
description: Studies in selected areas of Chicano/Latino Studies. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
repeatability: May be repeated for credit unlimited times.

name: Honors Research Preparation
description: Students write a proposal describing their research question, the relevant background literature, and the method of data collection and analysis.  Field work for the project may begin this quarter.
restriction: Open only to students in the Honors Program in Chicano/Latino Studies.

name: Honors Field Research
description: Students begin or continue their research for their senior honors thesis.

name: Honors Thesis
description: Student drafts a senior honor thesis (typically) with the following sections:  problem statement, literature review, description of the methods, results, and conclusions.

name: Honors Thesis
description: Student drafts a senior honor thesis (typically) with the following sections:  problem statement, literature review, description of the methods, results, and conclusions.

name: Group Directed Study
description: Directed study with Chicano/Latino faculty.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.

name: Independent Study
description: Independent research with Chicano/Latino faculty.
repeatability: May be repeated for credit unlimited times.

name: Theoretical Issues in Chicano/Latino Research
description: Introduction to theoretical issues in the scholarship in Chicano/Latino Studies. Theories from social sciences, humanities, critical theory. Topics: immigration, identity, gender and sexuality, globalization, transnationalism, social, political, and economic integration, race theory, labor market participation, social history, cultural productions.

name: Cultural and Historial Precedents for Latinos and Medical Care
description: Introduction to the history of Latinos, focusing on relevant pre-Columbian, colonial, and modern social and cultural developments, including issues of race, gender, sexuality, religious beliefs, and health beliefs and practices.

name: Cultural and Historical Precedents for Latinos and Medical Care
description: Introduction to the history of Latinos, focusing on relevant pre-Columbian, colonial, and modern social and cultural developments, including issues of race, gender, sexuality, religious beliefs, and health beliefs and practices.
restriction: Chicano/Latino Studies 210A-B and 212 may not both be taken for credit.

name: Latinos/Latinas and Medical Care: Contemporary Issues
description: Introduction to medical anthropological and social science perspectives on Latinos/Latinas in relation to a number of health and medically-related issues, i.e., immigration, gender, reproduction, culture, social structure, political economy, sexuality, utilization of medical services, and health beliefs.

name: Latinos/Latinas and Medical Care: Contemporary Issues
description: Introduction to medical anthropological and social science perspectives on Latinos/Latinas in relation to a number of health and medically-related issues, i.e., immigration, gender, reproduction, culture, social structure, political economy, sexuality, utilization of medical services, and health beliefs.

name: Transnational Migration
description: Examines borders and boundaries as material and semiotic constructs. Drawing upon an array of literatures, but loosely situated in U.S. geo/biopolitics, explores transformative troublings of places, spaces, borders, and bodies of all sorts.
restriction: Graduate students only.

name: Ethnography
description: Explores the theory and practice of ethnography with a focus on anthropology, the discipline most associated with ethnography. Students will be exposed to the theoretical underpinnings of ethnographic work, traditional and innovative practices, and sample ethnographies.
restriction: Graduate students only.

name: Race, Ethnicity, and Social Control
description: Origins and organization of racialized social control, with emphasis on criminal justice. Racial politics of criminal/juvenile justice considered in comparative (historical and international) perspective. Exploration of theoretical and methodological issues for research on race, ethnicity, and social control.
restriction: Graduate students only.

name: Special Topics in Chicano/Latino Studies
description: Current research in Chicano/Latino Studies.
repeatability: May be repeated for credit unlimited times.

name: Dissertation Research
description: Dissertation research with Chicano/Latino faculty.
repeatability: May be taken for credit 10 times.
restriction: Graduate students only.

name: Independent Study
description: Independent study with Chicano/Latino Studies faculty.
repeatability: May be repeated for credit unlimited times.
restriction: Graduate students only.

name: Introduction to Theatre
description: An interactive introduction to the world of theatre that serves to develop an appreciation of theatrical arts, to establish an awareness of landmarks within the performance history, and to create an understanding of the collaborative roles and departments that exist.

name: The Rock and Roll Spectacle Show
description: A thorough overview to the development and cultural significance of the Rock 'n' Roll Spectacle show. Focus on historical and recent developments of the spectacle show, trends in the aesthetics of the field, and various sub-genres.

name: Performing Rock 'N' Roll
description: Explores major movements in the history of rock 'n' roll in terms of performance, not virtuosity necessarily of the performers as musicians, rather as performances of aesthetics in modes of embodied ideology, iconoclastic spectacle, mixed media fashion, and subcultural formation.

name: Performance Now
description: Exposes students to what is most current in the world of performance and theatre.  Begins with a series of lectures on the idea of performance, and the various theories that frame it.
restriction: Drama and Music Theatre majors have first consideration for enrollment.

name: Performing Culture
description: Culture, aesthetics, and ideology (combined in the concept "subculture") work to fashion social identities. Using theories and methodologies of performance studies, with an emphasis on American culture, this course explores why and how culture is reinforced through performance.

name: Culture in Performance
description: A three-quarter foundation series exploring the rich depth of theatre, drama, and other genres of performance across a wide variety of worldwide forms, for performer and audience.

name: Culture in Performance
description: A three-quarter foundation series exploring the rich depth of theatre, drama, and other genres of performance across a wide variety of worldwide forms, for performer and audience.

name: Culture in Performance
description: A three-quarter foundation series exploring the rich depth of theatre, drama, and other genres of performance across a wide variety of worldwide forms, for performer and audience.

name: Acting
description: A one-year course in basic acting technique and discipline. Stage technique and stage discipline. Freeing vocal and physical movement and liberating emotional power. Elementary stage movement and voice. Elimination of regionalisms in speech. Overcoming stage fright. Readings in acting theory.
repeatability: May be taken for credit 2 times.
restriction: Drama and Music Theatre majors have first consideration for enrollment.

name: Acting
description: A one-year course in basic acting technique and discipline. Improvisations and scenes. Rehearsal and presentation of at least two scenes with different partners. Developing stage contact with tactics in a “play” situation.
repeatability: May be taken for credit 2 times.
restriction: Drama and Music Theatre majors have first consideration for enrollment.

name: Acting
description: A one-year course in basic acting technique and discipline. Characterization, scenes and auditioning. Development of character in at least three rehearsed scenes from different plays. Script analysis and performance technique. Preparation of audition pieces. The profession of acting.
repeatability: May be taken for credit 2 times.
restriction: Drama and Music Theatre students have the first consideration for enrollment.

name: Movement for Actors
description: A studio course in fundamentals of stretch, strength, and alignment; exploring spatial awareness and physical control through mime isolations, techniques, and related improvisation.
repeatability: May be taken for credit 3 times.

name: Speech for the Theatre
description: A course aimed at (1) improving natural, clear, unaffected speech and (2) eliminating negative habits and regional accents: exercises for physical tension, vocal support, tone production, vocal quality, and articulation.
repeatability: May be repeated for credit unlimited times.
restriction: Drama and Music Theatre majors only.

name: Development of Drama
description: The development of Western Drama, concentrating on the drama’s intellectual, social, and artistic foundations. About 10 plays and supplementary critical material are read each quarter. Greek Drama through Shakespeare.
restriction: Drama and Music Theatre majors have first consideration for enrollment.

name: Development of Drama
description: The development of Western Drama, concentrating on the drama’s intellectual, social, and artistic foundations. About 10 plays and supplementary critical material are read each quarter. Restoration Drama through Ibsen.
restriction: Drama and Music Theatre majors have first consideration for enrollment.

name: Development of Drama
description: The development of Western Drama, concentrating on the drama’s intellectual, social, and artistic foundations. About 10 plays and supplementary material are read each quarter. Contemporary Drama. Post Naturalistic theatre.
restriction: Drama and Music Theatre majors have first consideration for enrollment.

name: Introduction to Costume Design
description: Introduction to the process and procedures employed by the costume designer for the theatre. The elements of design are discussed in the context of character development, historical period, and style. Exercises extend to drawing, rendering, and investigation of human proportions.
restriction: Drama and Music Theatre majors only.

name: Introduction to Scenic Design
description: Introduction to the principles and practice of scenic design. Weekly problems include research into various periods and styles of production with an emphasis on the conceptual idea. Perspective drawing, rendering, and model building are covered in studio exercises and assignments.
restriction: Drama and Music Theatre majors only.

name: Introduction to Lighting Design
description: Introduction to the principles, theories, and equipment employed by the lighting designer for the stage.  Areas of investigation include history, technology, and script analysis. Detailed studio attention is given to the theory and practice of design.
restriction: Drama and Music Theatre majors only.

name: Introduction to Sound Design
description: Principles, theories, equipment use, and terminology employed by the sound designer for the stage.  Areas of study include history, technology, and script analysis.  Focuses on the theory and practice of design.
restriction: Drama and Music Theatre majors only.

name: Introduction to Stage Management
description: A basic study of theatrical, dance, and opera stage management practices, forms, and methods, from first script reading to closing night.  Opportunity to observe professionals at work in regional and touring situations as available.
restriction: Drama and Music Theatre majors only.

name: History and Theories of Scenography
description: Explores the aesthetics of the stage and the evolution of scenery and costume in live performance as inspiration for today’s theatre analysts. Topics include shared vocabulary, historical trends, shifts in approaches, and focus briefs on leaders in the field.
restriction: Drama and Music Theatre majors only.

name: Topics in Advanced Stage Management
description: Nurtures a greater appreciation for the stage manager and his or her process, and supports students who are interested in pursuing a career in professional stage management.
repeatability: May be taken for credit 3 times as topics vary.

name: Music Theatre Workshop I
description: Basic vocal technique and characterization of musical theatre repertoire explored.
repeatability: May be taken for credit 2 times.

name: Directing I
description: Introduction to comprehensive directing process from pre-production to opening. Focus on fundamental skills: analysis, staging, action, actor coaching, and elements of design. Skills applied to scripted theatrical material. Develop a language for commenting on theatrical production. Attending and critiquing productions.

name: University Theatre
description: Rehearsal and performance in a faculty-directed,production.
repeatability: May be repeated for credit unlimited times.

name: Theatre Production:  Costume
description: The production courses are offered to give students the opportunity to participate in departmental productions. Students engage in the production and construction of designed work as well as its applied execution during performance.
repeatability: May be taken for credit for 24 units.
restriction: May be taken for credit for a maximum of 24 units provided productions change.

name: Theatre Production:  Scenic
description: The production courses are offered to give students the opportunity to participate in departmental productions. Students engage in the production and construction of designed work as well as its applied execution during performance.
repeatability: May be taken for credit for 24 units.
restriction: May be taken for credit for a maximum of 24 units provided productions change.

name: Theatre Production:  Lighting
description: The production courses are offered to give students the opportunity to participate in departmental productions. Students engage in the production and construction of designed work as well as its applied execution during performance.
repeatability: May be taken for credit for 24 units.
restriction: May be taken for credit for a maximum of 24 units provided productions change.

name: Theatre Production:  Stage Management
description: The production courses are offered to give students the opportunity to participate in departmental productions. Students engage in the production and construction of designed work as well as its applied execution during performance.
repeatability: May be taken for credit 24 times.
restriction: May be taken for credit for a maximum of 24 units provided productions change.

name: Theatre Production:  Audio
description: The production courses are offered to give students the opportunity to participate in departmental productions. Students engage in the production and construction of designed work as well as its applied execution during performance.
repeatability: May be taken for credit for 24 units.
restriction: May be taken for credit for a maximum of 24 units provided productions change.

name: Theatre Production: Theatre Management
description: The production courses are offered to give students the opportunity to participate in departmental productions. Students engage in the production and construction of designed work as well as its applied execution during performance.
repeatability: May be taken for credit for 24 units.
restriction: May be taken for credit for a maximum of 24 units provided productions change.

name: Lectures in Dramatic Literature
description: Courses include Medieval and Tudor Drama, Elizabethan and Jacobean Drama, Shakespeare, Restoration and Eighteenth Century Drama, Modern British Drama, Modern American Drama, Tragedy, and Comedy.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.
restriction: Drama and Music Theatre majors only.

name: Lectures in Dramatic Literature
description: Courses include Medieval and Tudor Drama, Elizabethan and Jacobean Drama, Shakespeare, Restoration and Eighteenth-Century Drama, Modern British Drama, Modern American Drama, Tragedy, and Comedy.
prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the lower-division writing requirement
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.
restriction: Drama and Music Theatre majors only.

prereq.value: Satisfactory completion of the lower-division writing requirement

name: Special Topics in Theory and Criticism
description: Discussion of recent major trends and ideas in critical theory, concentrating on in-depth readings and lectures in particular facets of theory and criticism: Derrida, Butler, Lacan, Deleuze, and others.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.
restriction: Drama and Music Theatre majors only.

name: Special Topics in Theory and Criticism
description: Discussion of recent major trends and ideas in critical theory, concentrating on in-depth readings and lectures in particular facets of theory and criticism: Derrida, Butler, Lacan, Deleuze, and others.
prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.
restriction: Drama and Music Theatre majors only.

prereq.value: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement

name: Special Topics in Classical Dramas
description: Designed to introduce students to various classical traditions-early Greek and Roman theatres, to be sure, but also, by way of comparison, the classical traditions of non-European cultures.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.
restriction: Drama and Music Theatre majors only.

name: Special Topics in Classical Dramas
description: Designed to introduce students to various classical traditions-early Greek and Roman theatres, to be sure, but also, by way of comparison, the classical traditions of non-European cultures.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.
restriction: Drama and Music Theatre majors only.

name: Special Topics in Early Modern and Neoclassical Theatre
description: Investigates aspects of European theatre and culture in the sixteenth, seventeenth, and eighteenth centuries; individual courses may focus on specific topics within this broad expanse.
prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the lower-division writing requirement
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.
restriction: Drama and Music Theatre majors only.

prereq.value: Satisfactory completion of the lower-division writing requirement

name: Special Topics in Early Modern and Neoclassical Theatre
description: Investigates aspects of European theatre and culture in the sixteenth, seventeenth, and eighteenth centuries; individual courses may focus on specific topics within this broad expanse.
prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the lower-division writing requirement
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.
restriction: Drama and Music Theatre majors only.

prereq.value: Satisfactory completion of the lower-division writing requirement

name: Special Topics in Nineteenth-Century Dramas
description: Looks at the various trends and conventions of theatres in the nineteenth century, both Euro-American and beyond, paying special attention to the culture and political milieu within which these various traditions appeared.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.
restriction: Drama and Music Theatre majors only.

name: Special Topics in Nineteenth-Century Dramas
description: Looks at the various trends and conventions of theatres in the nineteenth century, both Euro-American and beyond, paying special attention to the culture and political milieu within which these various traditions appeared.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.
restriction: Drama and Music Theatre majors only.

name: Special Topics in Modern and Contemporary Drama
description: An investigation into the many forms and permutations of modern (1880-1945), and contemporary (since 1945) drama, paying special attention to the historical and philosophical interpretations of text and performance.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.
restriction: Drama and Music Theatre majors only.

name: Special Topics in Modern and Contemporary Drama
description: An investigation into the many forms and permutations of modern (1880-1945), and contemporary (since 1945) drama, paying special attention to the historical and philosophical interpretations of text and performance.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.
restriction: Drama and Music Theatre majors only.

name: Introduction to Asian Theatre
description: An introduction to some of the major traditional theatrical forms and dramatic texts from India, China, and Japan.  Other than dramatic texts (in English translation), attention is also paid to theory, history, and performance styles of traditional Asian theatre.
restriction: Drama and Music Theatre majors only.

name: Asian American Theatre
description: An introduction to the history and development of Asian American theatre and drama. Besides play analysis, special attention is also paid to the history and politics of Asian American identity and experience, as well as to aspects of theatrical performance.
restriction: Drama and Music Theatre majors only.

name: Multicultural Theatres
description: A study of the history, culture, aesthetics, and literature of various traditional performing arts and their connections to the contemporary multicultural society.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.
restriction: Drama and Music Theatre majors only.

name: African American Film and Drama
description: A critical investigation of films and plays written by African Americans, with emphasis on dramaturgical and cinematic strategies, individual and collective representation, and the legacy of African American political struggle.
prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the lower-division writing requirement
restriction: Drama and Music Theatre majors only.

prereq.value: Satisfactory completion of the lower-division writing requirement

name: African American Film and Drama
description: A critical investigation of films and plays written by African Americans, with emphasis on dramaturgical and cinematic strategies, individual and collective representation, and the legacy of African American political struggle.
prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the lower-division writing requirement
restriction: Drama and Music Theatre majors only.

prereq.value: Satisfactory completion of the lower-division writing requirement

name: Advanced Topics in Performance
description: Addresses particular issues in theatre and performance that typically lie outside of regular course offerings. May address such issues as the theatre of the Avant Garde, performing gender, transversality and performance, body art, installation and performance art, among other topics.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.
restriction: Drama and Music Theatre majors only.

name: Advanced Topics in Performance
description: Addresses particular issues in theatre and performance that typically lie outside of regular course offerings. May address such issues as the theatre of the Avant Garde, performing gender, transversality and performance, body art, installation and performance art, among other topics.
prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.

prereq.value: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement

name: Intermediate Acting
description: Rehearsal and presentation of scenes from contemporary material. Focus on connection with scene partner, playing actions, and text analysis. Introduction to the credibility and theatricality of characterization and style.
prerequisite: DRAMA 30A and DRAMA 30B and DRAMA 30C with an average grade of B or better
repeatability: May be taken for credit 2 times.
restriction: Drama and Music Theatre majors only.

children.value: DRAMA 30C with an average grade of B

name: Writing for Performance
description: Completion of a full-length play or its equivalent; discussion of student writing and of relevant literary texts.
prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the lower-division writing requirement
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.
restriction: Drama and Music Theatre majors only.

prereq.value: Satisfactory completion of the lower-division writing requirement

name: Writing for Performance
description: Completion of a full-length play or its equivalent; discussion of student writing and of relevant literary texts.
prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the lower-division writing requirement
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.
restriction: Drama and Music Theatre majors only.

prereq.value: Satisfactory completion of the lower-division writing requirement

name: Studio for Advanced Movement for Actors
description: Studio course in conditioning and partnering techniques to the practice of contact improvisation. Contact improvisation is explored and applied in scene study.
repeatability: May be taken for credit 3 times.

name: Master Classes in Acting
description: Advanced acting in specialized areas including acting for the camera: situation comedy, commercials; auditioning and industry preparation; Shakespeare; Molière; Chekov; improvisation; advanced movement and voice and speech for the actor; self-starting; stage combat; repertory acting, singing; comedy; clowning; and masks.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.
restriction: Drama and Music Theatre majors only.

name: Music Theatre Acting
description: An acting class exclusive to the students in the B.F.A. in Music Theatre program.
restriction: Music Theatre majors only.

name: Music Theatre Workshop II
description: A workshop in audition technique and song interpretation.
repeatability: May be taken for credit 4 times.

name: Music Theatre Workshop I
description: Scene study and song repertoire examined by era for the advanced Music Theatre student. 1800's-1940.

name: Music Theatre Workshop II
description: Scene study and song repertoire examined by era for the advanced Music Theatre student. 1940's-1970's.

name: Music Theatre Workshop III
description: Scene study and song repertoire examined by era for the advanced Music Theatre student. 1970's-present.

name: Music Theatre Workshop IV
description: A performance class concentrating on role building. Work culminates with in-class performances of abbreviated versions of musicals.
repeatability: May be taken for credit 4 times.
restriction: Music Theatre majors and Drama graduate students only.

name: Music Theatre Singing
description: Private weekly voice lessons for the advanced Music Theatre student.
repeatability: May be taken for credit 9 times.
restriction: Music Theatre majors only.

name: NYSP-Preparation
description: Class preparation for the New York Satellite Program (NYSP) - an immersion experience in New York City for the musical theatre performer.
repeatability: May be taken for credit 2 times.

name: History of American Musical Theatre
description: A survey of the influential artists who produce, write, direct, and perform on America's musical stages. Surveys 1700s-1940s.
restriction: Drama and Music Theatre majors only.

name: History of American Musical Theatre
description: A survey of the influential artists who produce, write, direct, and perform on America's musical stages. Surveys 1940s-1970s.
restriction: Drama and Music Theatre majors only.

name: History of American Musical Theatre
description: A survey of the influential artists who produce, write, direct, and perform on America's musical stages. Surveys 1970s to present day.
restriction: Drama and Music Theatre majors only.

name: Music Proficiency for Actors
description: A musicianship class introducing basic musical terminology, theory, and sight singing skills.
repeatability: May be taken for credit 2 times.
restriction: Drama and Music Theatre majors only.

name: Costume Production Techniques
description: Studio instruction in pattern making, draping, millinery, and construction techniques.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.
restriction: Drama and Music Theatre majors only.

name: Lighting Composition
description: Provides an opportunity for students to pursue stage lighting composition in a studio atmosphere.  Laboratory practice includes weekly exercises in style and genre. Emphasis is placed on the realization of conceptual ideas.
repeatability: May be repeated for credit unlimited times.
restriction: Drama and Music Theatre majors only.

name: Topics in Theatre Design
description: Examines the various functions of scenery and costume: locale, historical period, mood, and atmosphere, with special assignments in each area. Discussion of problems in scenic metaphors and visualization, emphasizing techniques of planning and presentation (e.g., floor plans, models, and rendering).
repeatability: May be repeated for credit unlimited times.
restriction: Drama or Music Theatre majors only.

name: Proseminar in Theatre Design
description: Topics in theatre design.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.
restriction: Drama and Music Theatre majors only.

name: Light Plotting Techniques
description: A study of the development of theatrical lighting plots from initial conceptualization through final documentation.  Areas of emphasis include script analysis, visual approaches, equipment selection, and compositional qualities of light.
restriction: Drama and Music Theatre majors only.

name: History of Costume
description: A study of the development of dress and the influence of cultural factors on clothing from the time of Egyptians to Early Baroque.
restriction: Drama and Music Theatre majors only.

name: History of Costume
description: A study of the development of dress and the influence of cultural factors on clothing from late Baroque to World War I.
restriction: Drama and Music Theatre majors only.

name: Fabric Modification Techniques
description: Exploration of various dying, printing, painting, and texture modification techniques.
restriction: Drama and Music Theatre majors only.

name: Theatrical Mask Techniques
description: Design and construction of theatrical masks including paper mache, leather, plastics, and latex.  Projects employ traditional and contemporary techniques.
restriction: Drama and Music Theatre majors only.

name: Costume Rendering Techniques
description: Development of costume rendering skills and techniques. Explores collage, pastel, and ink and emphasizes watercolor.
repeatability: May be taken for credit 2 times.
restriction: Drama and Music Theatre majors only.

name: Script and Score
description: A form and analysis seminar discussing the libretto and score of landmark musicals.
prerequisite: Two courses from DRAMA 148A or DRAMA 148B or DRAMA 148C
restriction: Drama and Music Theatre majors only.

name: Song Repertoire
description: A song coaching class culminating in a song recital or showcase. Each quarter will feature a different composer, lyricist, or musical style.
repeatability: May be taken for credit 6 times.
restriction: Music Theatre majors only.

name: Intermediate Sound Design
description: A project-based analysis of the principles of sound design for the theatre. Projects are executed in the sound design studio and may include sound manipulation and recording. Emphasis is placed on the realization of conceptual ideas.
restriction: Drama and Music Theatre majors only.

name: Contemporary Dramatic Criticism and Theory
description: Reading and analysis of theories and critical approaches to contemporary theatre: Brecht, Artaud, and others who have contributed to the form and idea of the modern theatre. Writing of assigned exercises in dramatic criticism.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.
restriction: Drama and Music Theatre majors only.

name: Contemporary Dramatic Criticism and Theory
description: Reading and analysis of theories and critical approaches to contemporary theatre:  Brecht, Artaud, and others who have contributed to the form and idea of the modern theatre. Writing of assigned exercises in dramatic criticism.
prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the lower-division writing requirement
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.
restriction: Drama and Music Theatre majors only.

prereq.value: Satisfactory completion of the lower-division writing requirement

name: Acting Theory
description: A study of the theory of acting, with readings in Plato, Aristotle, Quintilian, Shakespeare, Diderot, Stanislavsky, Brecht, Strasberg, Meisner, Grotowski, and other theorists, ancient to contemporary.
restriction: Drama and Music Theatre majors only. Juniors only.

name: Dance Technique, Level I
description: Advanced beginner and intermediate dance training including musical theatre, ballet, jazz and contemporary modern techniques and repertoire.  Body conditioning is also a major component of the course.
repeatability: May be taken for credit 4 times.
restriction: Drama and Music Theatre majors only.

name: Dance Technique, Level I
description: Advanced beginner and intermediate dance training including musical theatre, ballet, jazz and contemporary modern techniques and repertoire.  Body conditioning is also a major component of the course.
repeatability: May be taken for credit 4 times.
restriction: Drama and Music Theatre majors only.

name: Dance Technique, Level II
description: Intermediate and advanced dance training including musical theatre, ballet, jazz and contemporary modern techniques and repertoire.  Body conditioning is also a major component of the course.
repeatability: May be taken for credit 4 times.
restriction: Drama and Music Theatre majors only.

name: Dance Technique, Level II
description: Intermediate and advanced dance training including musical theatre, ballet, jazz and contemporary modern techniques and repertoire.  Body conditioning is also a major component of the course.
repeatability: May be taken for credit 4 times.
restriction: Drama and Music Theatre majors only.

name: Directing II
description: The principles of stage directing, covering the director's functions in the areas of interpretation, composition, coaching, and styling a theatrical production. Directing exercises and projects; the final project is the preparation of a hypothetical proposal for a play production.
prerequisite: DRAMA 30A and DRAMA 30B and DRAMA 30C and DRAMA 40A and DRAMA 40B and DRAMA 40C
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.
restriction: Drama and Music Theater majors only.

name: Advanced Directing
description: A seminar in directorial organization and research.  Student prepares a textual and dramaturgical analysis, a production timetable, and a hypothetical production book of an assigned play.
repeatability: May be repeated for credit unlimited times.
restriction: Drama and Music Theatre majors only.

name: NYSP-Acting
description: New York Satellite Program acting classes taught by guest faculty in New York.
repeatability: May be taken for credit 2 times.

name: NYSP - Dance
description: New York Satellite Program dance classes in ballet, tap, jazz, and musical theatre styles taught by guest faculty in New York.
repeatability: May be taken for credit 2 times.

name: NYSP - Singing
description: New York Satellite Program private and group lessons in musical theatre singing taught by guest faculty in New York.
repeatability: May be taken for credit 2 times.

name: NYSP - Performance
description: New York Satellite Program rehearsals and public, staged readings of original musicals in New York.
repeatability: May be taken for credit 2 times.

name: NYSP-UCI Residency
description: New York Satellite Program follow-up classes and performances back on Irvine campus upon the return from New York.
repeatability: May be taken for credit 2 times.

name: Music Theatre Dance - Special Topics
description: Advanced dance classes in specialized areas including the dance styles of a choreographer (de Mille, Fosse, Robbins, Tune, Stroman), genre (tap, ballroom, jazz, swing, hip-hop), or in musical theatre choreography.
prerequisite: DRAMA 182A or DRAMA 182B or DRAMA 182C or DRAMA 183A or DRAMA 183B or DRAMA 183C
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.
restriction: Drama and Music Theatre majors only.

name: Director Class Project
description: For students who are involved in the Director Class Projects at UCI as actors, directors, designers, stage managers and their assistants. M.F.A. Directors and the Head of Directing (HoD) supervise the projects.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.

name: Honors Director Class Project
description: For graduate student actors and undergraduate directors who are candidates for Honors in Directing and involved in the Director Class Projects. The Head of Directing (HoD) supervises these students.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.

name: Project in Theatre
description: Independent theatre projects with Drama faculty.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.

name: Graduate Studio: Acting
description: Work in graduate studio taken in tandem with graduate studios in stage voice (DRAMA 201), stage speech (DRAMA 202), and stage movement (DRAMA 203).
repeatability: May be repeated for credit unlimited times.
restriction: Drama graduate students and Drama and Theatre graduate students only.

name: Graduate Studio: Voice
description: Graduate studio in vocal production for actors.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.
restriction: Drama graduate students and Drama and Theatre graduate students only.

name: Graduate Studio: Speech
description: Graduate studio in speech for actors.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.
restriction: Drama graduate students and Drama and Theatre graduate students only.

name: Graduate Studio: Movement
description: Work in graduate studio: stage movement taken in tandem with nine graduate studios in acting (DRAMA 200), voice (DRAMA 201), speech (DRAMA 202), and voice/movement dynamics (DRAMA 206).
repeatability: May be repeated for credit unlimited times.
restriction: Drama graduate students and Drama and Theatre graduate students only.

name: Graduate Studio: Voice/Movement Dynamics
description: Daily conditioning exercises.
repeatability: May be repeated for credit unlimited times.
restriction: Drama graduate students and Drama and Theatre graduate students only.

name: Graduate Studio: Directing
description: Graduate studio in directing.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.
restriction: Drama graduate students only.

name: Graduate Studio: Playwriting
description: Completion of a full-length play or its equivalent and production of a staged reading of the play at the end of the spring quarter.  Discussion of relevant literary texts and student writings.
repeatability: May be repeated for credit unlimited times.
restriction: Drama graduate students and Drama and Theatre graduate students only.

name: Graduate Master Class
description: Various topics such as Shakespeare, comedy, Molière, improvisation, Kabuki, television acting.
repeatability: May be repeated for credit unlimited times.
restriction: Drama graduate students and Drama and Theatre graduate students only.

name: Seminar in Dramatic Literature
description: Topics in Dramatic Literature.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.
restriction: Drama graduate students and Drama and Theatre graduate students only.

name: Seminar in Criticism
description: Topics in criticism.
restriction: Graduate students only.

name: Seminar on Theatre Pedagogy
description: A seminar on the major teaching systems in the dramatic arts with particular attention to professional arts training. Required prior to applying for Teaching Assistantships in studio areas.
restriction: Drama graduate students only.

name: Communication Skills for Graduate Students
description: Teaches basic public speaking techniques to graduate students, aids students in presenting persuasively for audiences large and small.

name: Graduate Projects
description: Various projects depending on student’s concentration (acting, design, musical theatre, directing).
repeatability: May be repeated for credit unlimited times.
restriction: Drama graduate students and Drama and Theatre graduate students only.

name: Singing Pedagogy
description: Learning how to teach voice lessons and coach musical theatre singing. Experiences include both private voice lessons and observing the lessons given to the B.F.A./Music Theatre students.
repeatability: May be taken for credit 3 times.
restriction: Graduate Music Direction students only.

name: Conducting
description: Private conducting instruction to develop freedom of movement/expression, baton technique, ear training, and tempo memory for both rehearsal and performance situations in musical theatre.
repeatability: May be taken for credit 9 times.
restriction: Graduate Music Directors only.

name: Script and Score
description: A form and analysis seminar discussing the libretto and score of landmark musicals.
restriction: M.F.A. in Music Direction students only.

name: Dramaturgy: Theory and Methods
description: Examines the practice, place, and theory of dramaturgy.  Explores plays in terms of how they work: dramatic form and structure, historical context, and more. Study includes dramaturgy as a theatrical practice.
restriction: Drama M.F.A. and Ph.D. students only.

name: Musical Scene Study I
description: Musically directing scenes from musicals of various time periods. Features works from the late 19th and early 20th centuries, including songwriters Gilbert and Sullivan, Irving Berlin, George Gershwin, Rodgers and Hart, and Cole Porter.
repeatability: May be taken for credit 3 times.
restriction: Graduate Music Director students only.

name: Musical Scene Study II
description: Musically directing scenes from musicals of various time periods. Features works from the middle of the 20th century including songwriters Rodgers and Hammerstein, Lerner and Loewe, Julie Styne, Kander and Ebb, and Jerry Herman.
repeatability: May be taken for credit 3 times.
restriction: Graduate Music Directors only.

name: Musical Scene Study III
description: Musically directing scenes from musicals of various time periods.  Features works from the late 20th and early 21st centuries including songwriters Stephen Sondheim, Andrew Lloyd Webber, Stephen Schwartz, Flaherty and Ahrens, and Jeanine Tesori.
repeatability: May be taken for credit 3 times.
restriction: Graduate Music Directors only.

name: Musicals Abridged
description: Musically directing abridged versions of musicals from various time periods and genres.
repeatability: May be taken for credit 3 times.
restriction: Graduate Music Directors only.

name: History of American Music Theatre
description: A survey of the influential artists who produce, write, direct, and perform on America's musical stages. Surveys 1700s-1940s.
restriction: Graduate only.

name: History of American Musical Theatre
description: A survey of the influential artists who produce, write, direct and perform on America's musical stages. Surveys 1940s-1970s.
restriction: Graduate only.

name: History of American Musical Theatre
description: A survey of the influential artists who produce, write, direct and perform on America's musical stages. Surveys 1970s to present day.

name: Graduate Music Direction
description: Various musical direction activities including the vocal direction, accompanying, and conducting of musical theatre performances.
repeatability: May be taken for credit 9 times.
restriction: M.F.A. in Music Direction students only.

name: Foundations of Theatre
description: Seeks to create greater understanding in the roots and theories of theatrical models, aesthetics, action vs. reaction of differing thoughts in theatrical doctrine, and art, architecture, music, and fashion that contributed to the style and practice of theatre.
restriction: Drama graduate students only.

name: Foundations of Theatre
description: Seeks to create greater understanding in the roots and theories of theatrical models, aesthetics, action vs. reaction of differing thoughts in theatrical doctrine, and art, architecture, music, and fashion that contributed to the style and practice of theatre.
restriction: Drama graduate students only.

name: Foundations of Theatre
description: Seeks to create greater understanding in the roots and theories of theatrical models, aesthetics, action vs. reaction of differing thoughts in theatrical doctrine, and art, architecture, music, and fashion that contributed to the style and practice of theatre.
restriction: Drama graduate students only.

name: Graduate Stage Management
description: Studio exercises and projects in stage management.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.
restriction: Open only to Drama graduate students pursuing Stage Management emphasis.

name: Graduate Design Seminar
description: Projects, lectures, and critical discussion in costume, scenery, lighting, and sound design.
restriction: Open only to Drama graduate students pursuing Design emphasis.

name: Survival and Professional Practice in Design
description: Provides an in-depth examination of business skills needed to survive as a theatrical designer. Required 'Bridge' course in the Design MFA programs, relevant to all disciplines.
restriction: Drama graduate students only.

name: Costume Thesis Project
description: Development of thesis project with focus on organization, research, timeline, and execution.
restriction: Drama graduate students only.

name: Scenic Thesis Project
description: Development of thesis project with focus on organization, research, timeline, and execution.

name: Thesis Writing Project-Stage Management
description: Development of thesis topic with focus on organization, research, timeline, and execution.
restriction: Drama graduate students only.

name: Drawing for Designers
description: A multi-skill level course in drawing technique focusing on skills essential to stage designers including line, proportion, perspective and creating dynamic compositions. Focus will primarily be in figure drawing but may include still-life, landscape, and architectural drawings. Materials fee.
repeatability: May be taken for credit 9 times.

name: Theatre Colloquium
description: Exposes students to a wider range of theatrical practitioners, theories, and topics through guest lecturers, special projects, and cross-disciplinary dialogue.
repeatability: May be repeated for credit unlimited times.
restriction: Drama graduate students and Drama and Theatre graduate students only.

name: Digital Costume Rendering
description: A studio course in costume rendering for the theatre using computer image manipulation. Instruction in compositing and painting techniques and performance design conventions.

name: Digital Textile Design and Printing
description: A studio course in textile design using digital printing and embossing techniques. Instruction in state-of-the-art software and output manipulation for artistic expression.

name: Digital Design: Drawing/Painting/Rendering
description: A studio course in scenic or costume rendering for the theatre using the computer for drawing/painting through the use of the digital pen/tablet.
repeatability: May be taken for credit 2 times.
restriction: Drama graduate students and Drama and Theatre graduate students only.

name: Digital Design: 2D/3D Modeling
description: A studio course in CAD's 2D drafting and 3D modeling capabilities for theatrical design. Instruction in state-of-the-art software for 2D and 3D object creation and theatrical presentation conventions.
restriction: Drama graduate students and Drama and Theatre graduate students only.

name: Digital Design: 3D Rendering
description: A studio course in theatrical design through 3d modeling on computer and use of state-of-the-art rendering software. Instruction emphasizes collaborative design process through the use of scenic designer/lighting designer teams for all projects.
restriction: Drama graduate students and Drama and Theatre graduate students only.

name: Lighting Graphics
description: A studio course in the various graphic methods employed by lighting designers in the theatre.  Projects include manual and CAD techniques for Light Plot and Paperwork creation.
restriction: Drama graduate students and Drama and Theatre graduate students only.

name: Digital Design: 2D CAD
description: A studio course in theatrical design and architectural lighting design on the computer.  Instruction in state-of-the-art software for 2D object creation.  Theatrical and architectural standards implemented in performance design.
restriction: Drama graduate students and Drama and Theatre graduate students only.

name: Digital Design:  Digital Audio Systems
description: Comprehensive tutorial on digital audio including hard disk recording, editing, data compression, and ethernet audio distribution.  Focus is on recording, editing, and delivery of audio as used by the sound designer in the digital domain.
restriction: Drama graduate students only.

name: Digital Design: Creating Sounds from Scratch
description: The process of analyzing sounds for their core timbral components and using that data to create new sounds - from realistic to fantastic - by means of digital manipulation.
restriction: Open only to Drama graduate students pursuing Sound Design emphasis.

name: Conceptual Sound Design
description: An intensive, project-based seminar for exploring relationships between sound and sight.  Synesthesia, creative intent vs. audience perception, and sound/movement are typical of the many topics to be explored.  A series of creative projects are assigned and critiqued in peer review.
restriction: Open only to Drama graduate students pursuing Sound Design emphasis.

name: Musical Theatre Sound/Concert Sound
description: A concept-to-opening study of the process of designing sound systems for musicals and live/touring sound.  Special attention given to the paperwork and documentation required to package, build, and mix these shows.
restriction: Open only to Drama graduate students pursuing Sound Design emphasis.

name: Critical Listening
description: Exploration of the many variables that affect (and effect) the audio chain.  Perceiving and understanding these parameters unlocks the art of controlling sound and stylizing cues.  Also includes the process of equalizing/aligning sound systems and the art of audio mastering.
restriction: Open only to Drama graduate students pursuing Sound Design emphasis.

name: Advanced Sound Design
description: An in-depth investigation into sound design for the theatre. Special emphasis is placed on text analysis, design conception, content creation, content delivery, and design organization. Class projects include creating paper designs and paperwork for different texts.

name: Techniques in Costume Design
description: Student exercises in the techniques and implementation of costume design.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.
restriction: Open only to Drama graduate students pursuing Costume Design emphasis.

name: Techniques in Scenery Design
description: Student exercises in the techniques and implementation of scenic design.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.
restriction: Open only to Drama graduate students pursuing Scenic Design emphasis.

name: Techniques in Lighting Design
description: Student exercises in the techniques and implementation of lighting design.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.
restriction: Open only to Drama graduate students pursuing Lighting Design emphasis.

name: Techniques in Sound Design
description: Student exercises in the techniques and implementation of sound design.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.
restriction: Open only to Drama graduate students pursuing Sound Design emphasis.

name: Stage Electronics/Introduction to Show Control
