Learner-centered approach develops reading, writing, speaking, listening, grammatical, and cultural skills and knowledge.
restriction: GERMAN S2BC and GERMAN 2B and GERMAN 2C may not be taken for full credit.

name: Science, Society, and Mind
description: Historical, philosophical, and literary reflections by German writers on the rise of the modern sciences. In English. Designed primarily for nonmajors.
repeatability: May be taken for credit 3 times as topics vary.

name: Advanced Conversation
description: Includes reading of political and cultural material. Conducted in German.
repeatability: May be repeated for credit unlimited times.

name: Fundamentals of German (with Emphasis on Reading)
description: Primarily for students interested in acquiring a solid reading knowledge of German. Facilitates comprehension and translation of texts in various disciplines. Does not serve as prerequisite for any higher-level German courses or fulfill any undergraduate foreign language requirement.
repeatability: May be taken for credit 3 times.
restriction: Non-German majors only.

name: Introduction to German Literature and Culture
description: Sample interpretations of texts in their cultural and historical contexts. Introduction to critical language in German.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.

name: German Culture and Society
description: Interdisciplinary introduction to German culture from the perspective of its aesthetic, social, and political aspects. Methodological problems arising from an analysis of culture in its historical context.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.

name: German Film
description: Introduction to the history and interpretation of German film within its cultural and social contexts. Enhances German grammar knowledge and vocabulary and develops sophisticated speaking, writing, and reading skills.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.

name: Introduction to Germanic Linguistics
description: Introduces German or other Germanic-language linguistic, sociolinguistic, or ethnography-of-communication topics. Taught in German.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.

name: German for Professions
description: Explores the structure of German business practices, including in scientific fields and engineering, while developing verbal and written skills important for professional life in Germany. Taught in German.

name: Advanced German for Business and Economics
description: Explores the structure of the German economy and business practices while developing advanced verbal and written skills important for professional life in Germany. Taught in German.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.

name: Topics in German Literature and Culture 750-1750
description: Specific course content determined by individual faculty members. Example: Luther and the European Renaissance.
prerequisite: GERMAN 101 or GERMAN 102 or GERMAN 103 or GERMAN 104
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.

name: Studies in the Age of Goethe
description: Individual authors such as Lessing, Goethe, Schiller, Kleist, and Hölderlin, or the drama of the "angry young men" of the German 1770s.
prerequisite: GERMAN 101 or GERMAN 102 or GERMAN 103 or GERMAN 104
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.

name: Studies in Nineteenth-Century German Literature and Culture
description: Individual authors such as Büchner, Grillparzer, Keller, and Nietzsche, or broader social-literary phenomena.
prerequisite: GERMAN 101 or GERMAN 102 or GERMAN 103 or GERMAN 104
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.

name: Studies in Twentieth Century German Literature and Culture
description: Individual authors such as Thomas Mann, Brecht, and Kafka, or topics addressing questions of genre and/or social-literary problems.
prerequisite: GERMAN 101 or GERMAN 102 or GERMAN 103 or GERMAN 104
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.

name: Topics in German Literature and Culture
description: Literary and cultural topics not fully contained within the periods listed above, such as "German Comedy" and "Turn-of-the-Century Vienna.".
prerequisite: GERMAN 101 or GERMAN 102 or GERMAN 103 or GERMAN 104
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.

name: Topics in Literary Theory and Criticism
description: In English. Theoretical dimensions of literary criticism and the German philosophical tradition. Topics have included Marxism, Freudian thought, German Idealist aesthetics, Historicism, twentieth-century hermeneutics, Frankfurt School, and Rezeptionsästhetik.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.

name: Topics in Literary Theory and Criticism
description: In English. Theoretical dimensions of literary criticism and the German philosophical tradition. Topics have included Marxism, Freudian thought, German Idealist aesthetics, Historicism, twentieth-century hermeneutics, Frankfurt School, and Rezeptionsaesthetik.
prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.
restriction: Upper-division students only.

prereq.value: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement

name: German Literature and Culture in Translation
description: In English. Major works in Germanic literature and culture in context.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.

name: German Literature and Culture in Translation
description: In English. Major works in Germanic literature and culture in context.
prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.
restriction: Upper-division students only.

prereq.value: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement

name: German Cinema
description: Historical, theoretical, and comparative perspectives on German cinema.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.

name: German Cinema
description: Historical, theoretical, and comparative perspectives on German cinema.
prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.
restriction: Upper-division students only.

prereq.value: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement

name: Topics in German Linguistics
description: Explores linguistic, sociolinguistic, or ethnography-of-communication topics of German or other Germanic languages (Swedish, Icelandic, Yiddish, and others). Taught in English.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.

name: Topics in German Linguistics
description: Explores linguistic, sociolinguistic, or ethnography-of-communication topics of German or other Germanic languages (Swedish, Icelandic, Yiddish, and others). Taught in English.
prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.
restriction: Upper-division students only.

prereq.value: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement

name: German Internship
description: In this internship course, students will engage in professional practice (e.g., Engineering, Business Administration, government) in a German setting and thereby increase their knowledge of German language and culture in a setting beyond the academic classroom.

name: Independent Study
description: Independent research with German faculty.
repeatability: May be repeated for credit unlimited times.

name: Literary Criticism
description: Topics in literary criticism.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.
restriction: Graduate students only.

name: Literary Theory
description: Topics in literary theory.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.
restriction: Graduate students only.

name: Selected Topics in German Linguistics
description: Topics in German linguistics.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.
restriction: Graduate students only.

name: Literary and Cultural History
description: Topics in literary and cultural history.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.
restriction: Graduate students only.

name: Independent Study
description: Counted toward course requirements for the M.A. or Ph.D. A term paper or project is required.
repeatability: May be repeated for credit unlimited times.
restriction: Graduate students only. School of Humanities majors only.

name: Independent Directed Reading
description: For students preparing for doctoral examination.
repeatability: May be repeated for credit unlimited times.
restriction: Graduate students only.

name: Dissertation Research
description: For students who have been admitted to doctoral candidacy.
repeatability: May be repeated for credit unlimited times.
restriction: Graduate students only. School of Humanities majors only.

name: University Teaching
description: Limited to Teaching Assistants.
repeatability: May be repeated for credit unlimited times.
restriction: Graduate students only.

name: Fundamentals of Greek
description: Elements of Classical Greek grammar, syntax, and vocabulary.
restriction: GREEK 1A and GREEK S1AB may not be taken for full credit.

name: Fundamentals of Greek
description: Elements of Classical Greek grammar, syntax, and vocabulary.
restriction: GREEK 1B and GREEK S1AB and GREEK S1BC may not be taken for full credit.

name: Fundamentals of Greek
description: Introduction to reading texts.
restriction: GREEK 1C and GREEK S1BC may not be taken for full credit.

name: Fundamentals of Greek
description: First half of first- year Greek in an intensified form.
restriction: GREEK S1AB and GREEK 1A and GREEK 1B may not be taken for full credit.

name: Fundamentals of Greek
description: Second half of first- year Greek in an intensified form.
restriction: GREEK S1BC and GREEK 1B and GREEK 1C may not be taken for full credit.

name: Introduction to Biblical Greek
description: An inductive approach to learning to read Biblical Greek texts. Basic grammar, syntax, morphology, and vocabulary presented within the context of reading. Course is not a substitute for GREEK 1A, GREEK 1B, and GREEK 1C series.

name: Special Studies in Greek
description: Lower-division level independent research with Greek faculty.
repeatability: May be repeated for credit unlimited times.

name: Topics in  Attic Greek
description: Selected readings in Attic Greek prose and poetry. Authors may include Xenophon, Lysias, Antiphon, Euripides, and others. Selections from prose and poetry will be read each quarter. Grammar and syntax review included.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.

name: Seminar in Greek Prose
description: Specialized and focused study of a particular Greek prose author or topic.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.

name: Seminar in Greek Poetry
description: Specialized and focused study of a particular topic or author of Greek poetry.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.

name: Reading of Selected Portions of the New Testament
description: Studies in selected areas of the New Testament. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.

name: Directed Group Study
description: Special topics in Greek culture and civilization through directed reading and research.
repeatability: May be repeated for credit unlimited times.

name: Independent Studies in Greek
description: Independent research with Greek faculty.
repeatability: May be repeated for credit unlimited times.

name: Fundamentals of Hebrew
description: Designed for students with little or no exposure to Hebrew. Introduction to modern Israeli Hebrew. Students learn the writing system and basics of grammar via latest pedagogical materials and real-world texts. Topics in Jewish culture and Biblical Hebrew are included.

name: Fundamentals of Hebrew
description: Designed for students with little or no exposure to Hebrew. Introduction to modern Israeli Hebrew. Students learn the writing system and basics of grammar via latest pedagogical materials and real-world texts. Topics in Jewish culture and Biblical Hebrew are included.

name: Fundamentals of Hebrew
description: Designed for students with little or no exposure to Hebrew. Introduction to modern Israeli Hebrew. Students learn the writing system and basics of grammar via latest pedagogical materials and real-world texts. Topics in Jewish culture and Biblical Hebrew are included.

name: Intermediate Hebrew
description: Designed for students to advance their Hebrew language skills from introductory to intermediate level. Emphasizes development of meaningful communicative skills and critical study of Hebrew culture. Students develop reading, writing, speaking, listening, grammatical, and cultural skills.
restriction: School of Humanities and International Studies majors have first consideration for enrollment.

name: Intermediate Hebrew
description: Designed for students to advance their Hebrew language skills from introductory to intermediate level. Emphasizes development of meaningful communicative skills and critical study of Hebrew culture. Students develop reading, writing, speaking, listening, grammatical, and cultural skills.
restriction: School of Humanities and International Studies majors have first consideration for enrollment.

name: Intermediate Hebrew
description: Designed for students to advance their Hebrew language skills from introductory to intermediate level. Emphasizes development of meaningful communicative skills and critical study of Hebrew culture. Students develop reading, writing, speaking, listening, grammatical, and cultural skills.
restriction: School of Humanities and International Studies majors have first consideration for enrollment.

name: Hebrew Peer-to-Peer Language Mentor Program
description: Peer-to-Peer Language Mentor Program in which student mentors work with student mentees to increase the language skills of both participants. One hour weekly meetings. HEBREW 10A is for language mentors.
repeatability: May be taken for credit 4 times.

name: Hebrew Peer-to-Peer Language Mentor Program
description: Peer-to-Peer Language Mentor Program in which student mentors work with student mentees to increase the language skills of both participants. One hour weekly meetings. HEBREW 10B is for language mentors.
repeatability: May be taken for credit 4 times.

name: Jewish and Israeli Culture
description: Examination of subjects relevant to the culture of Israel and Judaism in their historical and modern day contexts through the study of film, literature, religious texts, artistic representations, etc.

name: Independent Study
description: Research paper required.
repeatability: May be repeated for credit unlimited times.

name: Responding to Dynamic Times: Thinking Strategically for Healthcare Executives
description: Focuses on the strategic and organizational challenges that a rapidly changing environment poses to the firm’s management and frames them according to Merage’s strategic emphasis on analytical decision making, innovation, and information technology.
restriction: Health Care Executive M.B.A. students only.

name: Statistics for Healthcare Executives
description: Methods of statistical inference, emphasizing applications to administrative and management decision problems. Topics include classical estimation, hypothesis testing, regression, correlation, analysis of variance, decision analysis, and forecasting.  Course may be offered online.
restriction: Health Care Executive M.B.A. students only.

name: Operations Analytics for Healthcare Executives
description: An introduction to computer-based models for decision making. Topics include optimization (linear programming, integer programming, network flow models) and computer simulation. Uses spreadsheets extensively, including Excel built-in and add-in packages. Once a month weekend course format.
restriction: Health Care Executive M.B.A. students only.

name: Organizational Behavior for Healthcare Executives
description: Develops a better understanding of individual and group behavior in and across organizations, the frameworks by which to analyze and understand behavior in complex organizations; enhances the skills required to manage collaboration and lead. Once a month weekend course format.
restriction: Health Care Executive M.B.A. students only.

name: Financial Reporting for Healthcare Executives
description: Involves the development, analysis, and interpretation of financial accounting information for external reporting purposes. Emphasis on measurement and valuation issues in decision-making problems and cases.  Once a month weekend course format.
restriction: Health Care Executive M.B.A. students only.

name: Managerial Accounting for Healthcare Executives
description: Involves developing and using internal financial and non-financial information to help organizations make planning, budgeting, control, operating, and performance evaluation decisions.  Once a month weekend course format.
restriction: Health Care Executive M.B.A. students only.

name: Microeconomics for Healthcare Executives
description: Provides basic tools for analyzing economic decisions of consumers and firms. Topics include demand and supply analysis, production and cost theory, perfect competition, monopoly, market failures, and introductory game theory. Once a month weekend course format.
restriction: Health Care Executive M.B.A. students only.

name: Macroeconomics for Healthcare Executives
description: Introduces use of macroeconomic analysis to manage the business cycle for competitive advantage. "Business cycle-sensitive" management is explored within the context of marketing, operations management, HRM, merger and acquisitions, and capital financing and expenditures.  Once a month weekend course format.
restriction: Health Care Executive M.B.A. students only.

name: Marketing for Healthcare Executives
description: Introduction to marketing. Develops familiarity with fundamental marketing concepts, theories, and techniques, and acquainting students with the type of decisions made by marketing managers, including customer targeting, product, pricing, place, promotion, and research. Once a month weekend course format.
restriction: Health Care Executive M.B.A. students only.

name: Business and Government for Healthcare Executives
description: Introduces students to the many non-market issues that affect today's managers: environment protection, health and safety, intellectual property protection, antitrust, and lobbying. Takes an interdisciplinary approach using economics, political science, public policy, and law. Once a month weekend course format.
restriction: Health Care Executive M.B.A. students only.

name: Information Technology for Healthcare Executives
description: Focuses on how information technology is used to create value in healthcare-related organizations through product, process, and strategy innovation. Aims to help managers and healthcare professionals understand the strategic role of technology. Every other weekend course format.
restriction: Health Care Executive M.B.A. students only.

name: Managerial Finance for Healthcare Executives
description: Introduces students to financial theory and concepts. Topics include time value of money, valuation of stocks and bonds, capital budgeting, portfolio theory, capital structure choice. Once a month weekend course format.
prerequisite: MGMT HC 201A and MGMT HC 203A and MGMT HC 204A
restriction: Health Care Executive M.B.A. students only.

name: Investments for Healthcare Executives
description: Foundations of investment management. Theory and empirical evidence related to portfolio theory, market efficiency, and valuation models for equities, bonds, and options.  Emphasis on practical applications, including optimal investment strategies. Once a month weekend course format.
restriction: Health Care Executive M.B.A. students only.

name: Strategic Management for Healthcare Executives
description: Provides conceptual frameworks and techniques to analyze and develop firm strategies. Through case analysis and discussion, helps students improve analytical and strategic thinking by which to assess, evaluate, and respond to different business situations. Once a month weekend course format.
prerequisite: MGMT HC 200 and MGMT HC 202 and MGMT HC 205 and MGMT HC 209A
restriction: Health Care Executive M.B.A. students only.

name: Entrepreneurship for Healthcare Executives
description: A project course in which student teams develop a business plan to launch a new venture. Drafts of sections of the plan are due throughout the course. Once a month weekend course format.
restriction: Master of Business Administration graduate students only.

name: Negotiations For Healthcare Executives
description: Using a combination of theory and practice via negotiation simulations, students expand their repertoire of negotiating skills and develop their ability to analyze different negotiation situations and contexts. Once a month weekend course format.
restriction: Master of Business Administration students only.

name: Understanding Managed Care
description: This course is designed to increase understanding of the various concepts of managed health care with an emphasis on the organizational processes required to make it work, and explore the economics and financial pressures these organizations face.
restriction: Masters of Business Administration graduate students only.

name: Special Topics in Business
description: Studies in selected areas of business. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
repeatability: May be repeated for credit unlimited times.
restriction: Masters of Business Administration students only.

name: Business Law for Healthcare Executives
description: Detailed study from a business viewpoint of contract theories, assignments, delegation of duties, third-party beneficiary contracts, defenses to consensual contracts, types of conditions, methods of excusing conditions, remedies, and types of damages.
repeatability: May be repeated for credit unlimited times.
restriction: Masters of Business Administration graduate students only.

name: Federal Policy in Health Care
description: National/international one-week residential course exploring political analysis as related to management of health care organizations.  Topics include political environment of management, concepts, and processes central to political analysis, bureaucratic politics, politics, and the manager.
restriction: Health Care Executive M.B.A. students only.

name: Leadership for Healthcare Executives
description: Focuses on the conceptual, practical, and personal dimensions of executive leadership. Past and current leadership theories are addressed. Individual personal assessment and diagnosis. Once a month weekend course format.
restriction: Healthcare Executive M.B.A. students only.

name: Individual Study
description: Individual study under the direction of a selected faculty member.
repeatability: May be repeated for credit unlimited times.
restriction: Master of Business Administration students only.

name: Humanities and Arts: Problems and Methods for Global Middle East Studies
description: Introduces students to the broad set of humanities and arts approaches to studying the Middle East as a global zone of cultural, political, and economic interaction.

name: Social Sciences: Problems and Methods for Global Middle East Studies
description: Introduces students to the broad set of social sciences approaches to studying the Middle East as a global zone of cultural, political, and economic interaction.

name: Social Ecology and Sciences: Problems and Methods for Global Middle East Studies
description: Introduces students to the broad set of approaches to studying the Middle East as a global zone of cultural, political, and economic interaction, focusing on the disciplines related to Social Ecology.

name: Research and Writing for Global Middle East Studies
description: Research and writing course for Global Middle East Studies majors. The primary focus is to refine the skills necessary for students to engage in independent research and writing in Global Middle East Studies.
corequisite: GLBL ME 60A or GLBL ME 60B or GLBL ME 60C
restriction: Global Middle East Studies majors have first consideration for enrollment.

name: The Holocaust
description: Introduction to the history of European Jewish communities before the Holocaust; the origins of Nazi antisemitism; the implementation of the "Final Solution"; Jewish resistance to the Nazis; and attempts in film and literature to represent the Holocaust since 1945.

name: Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity Since WWII
description: Investigates instances of genocide since 1945 (including Cambodia, Bosnia, Rwanda, and others); explores the history behind these mass murders; considers why people kill, how victims survive, and questions whether international agreements are enough to prevent crimes against humanity.

name: Introductory Topics in History
description: Introduces methods and premises of historical study. Topics include introductions to cultural, political, economic, social, and religious history.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.

name: Native American History
description: An overview of major developments in Indian-white relations from the American Revolution to the present with an emphasis on political and legal history. How tribal sovereignty has been redefined over time is a central theme of the course.

name: Asian American Histories
description: Examines and compares diverse experiences of major Asian American groups since the mid-nineteenth century. Topics include origins of emigration; the formation and transformation of community; gender and family life; changing roles of Asian Americans in American society. Formerly ASIANAM 60A.

name: History of Sexuality in the US
description: Explores intertwined histories of sexuality, race, and gender in the US. By examining how different cultures and times viewed sexuality, race and gender, it analyzes relationships between regulation of bodies/behaviors and construction of cultural, economic, and political norms.

name: Memory and Migration: American Families on the Move
description: Examines family migration stories as a tool for understanding the intertwined histories of international and domestic migration that have shaped the lives of the diverse peoples of the United States.

name: What to Eat? Immigrants and the Development of American Cuisines
description: Relationship between immigration and changing American foodways; impact of several major culinary traditions of immigrants and racial minorities, such as African Americans, Asian Americans, Mexican Americans, Italian Americans, Irish Americans, and Jewish Americans, on America’s gastronomical and socioeconomic landscape.

name: Racial Segregation in Modern U
description: Explores the history of racial segregation in the United States from the late 19th century to the present.

name: World Religions I
description: An introduction to the history, doctrine, culture, and writing of Judaism, Christianity, and Islam.

name: World Religions II
description: An introduction to various religious traditions in selected areas of the world—including India and South Asia, East Asia, Africa, and the Americas.

name: Religious Dialogue
description: Lectures and discussion on controversial topics in religion: sexual morality; religious violence; science; treatment of women and girls; religious truth, American Constitutional matters; secularization; the future of religion, and other topics.

name: Introduction to Jewish Cultures
description: Introduction to the diversity of Jewish cultures from ancient to modern times. Surveys the Jewish experience in various societies and civilizations: ancient Mediterranean, Middle East and North Africa, Europe, and the Americas.

name: World:  Innovations
description: Treats major themes of world historical development through the mid-seventeenth century, focusing on the Eurasian world, but with secondary emphasis on Africa and the Americas.

name: World: Empires and Revolutions
description: Examines three major transformations that made the world of 1870 dramatically different from that of 1650: e.g., the scientific revolution, industrialization, and the formation of modern states and nations.

name: World: Wars and Rights
description: Considers several major currents of modern history: technological change and its social effects; changes in gender relations; totalitarianism; peasant revolutions and the crisis of colonization; international migration; and ecological problems.

name: The Formation of Ancient Greek Society: Early Greece
description: A survey of ancient Greek civilization from its origins in the Bronze Age to the mid-Archaic period. Examines political and social history, as well as literature, art, religion, and archaeological remains.

name: The Formation of Ancient Greek Society:  Late Archaic and Classical Greece
description: A survey of ancient Greek civilization from the Late Archaic period to the Classical period. Focuses on major institutions and cultural phenomena as seen through the study of ancient Greek literature, history, archaeology, and religion.

name: The Formation of Ancient Greek Society: Fourth-Century and Hellenistic Greece
description: A survey of ancient Greek civilization from the fourth century BCE through to the Hellenistic period. Focuses on major institutions and cultural phenomena as seen through the study of ancient Greek literature, history, archaeology, and religion.

name: The Formation of Ancient Roman Society: Origins to Roman Republic
description: A survey of the development of Roman civilization from its eighth century BCE beginnings to the civil wars of the first century BCE. Examines political and social history, as well as literature, art, architecture, and religion.

name: The Formation of Ancient Roman Society: Roman Empire
description: A survey of Roman civilization from Augustus’s consolidation of power following the civil wars of the first century BCE to the crisis of the third century CE. Includes social history, literature, art, architecture, and religion.

name: The Formation of Ancient Roman Society: The Fall of Rome
description: A survey of Roman civilization from the crisis of the third century CE to the so-called “fall of Rome” in 476 CE.  Examines political and social history, as well as literature, art, architecture, and religion.

name: Colonial America:  New Worlds
description: Important themes in the social, economic, political, and cultural development in North America that transformed part of the geographical space into the U.S. Topics include Native Americans, European colonization, African enslavement, borderlands, gender, economic stratification, the American Revolution, the Constitution.
prerequisite: Satisfaction of the UC Entry Level Writing requirement

prereq.value: Satisfaction of the UC Entry Level Writing requirement

name: Nineteenth-Century U
description: Explores the transformation of American society, economy, and politics during the nineteenth century. Topics include industrial revolution, slavery, antislavery, women's rights, reform movements, Civil War and Reconstruction, immigration and ethnicity, and cultural and social transformation.
prerequisite: Satisfaction of the UC Entry Level Writing requirement

prereq.value: Satisfaction of the UC Entry Level Writing requirement

name: Modern America:  Culture and Power
description: Important themes in U.S. history in the twentieth and early twenty-first centuries. Topics include corporate capitalism, empire, immigration, race, gender, consumer society, World Wars, Progressiveness, New Deal, Great Society, civil rights, women's movements, Vietnam War, conservative politics, and economic stratification.
prerequisite: Satisfaction of the UC Entry Level Writing requirement

prereq.value: Satisfaction of the UC Entry Level Writing requirement

name: Crises and Revolutions
description: Study of turning points in world history, illustrating themes and methods of historical analysis.
repeatability: May be taken for credit 3 times as topics vary.

name: The Making of Modern Science
description: Surveys the history of science and mathematics since the Scientific Revolution, examining central developments both chronologically and thematically, as well as investigating their significance for contemporary philosophical debates about the role and status of current scientific theories.

name: Problems in History: Asia
description: An introduction to the historical problems, the issues of interpretation, the primary sources, and the historical scholarship of the history of Asia, with an emphasis on developing skills in historical essay-writing.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.

name: Problems in History: Europe
description: An introduction to the historical problems, the issues of interpretation, the primary sources, and the historical scholarship of the history of Europe, with an emphasis on developing skills in historical essay-writing.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.

name: Problems in History: United States
description: An introduction to the historical problems, the issues of interpretation, the primary sources, and the historical scholarship of the history of the United States, with an emphasis on developing skills in historical essay-writing.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.

name: Problems in History: Latin America
description: An introduction to the historical problems, the issues of interpretation, the primary sources, and the historical scholarship of the history of Latin America, with an emphasis on developing skills in historical essay-writing.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.

name: Problems in History: Middle East and Africa
description: An introduction to the historical problems, the issues of interpretation, the primary sources, and the historical scholarship of the history of the Middle East and Africa, with an emphasis on developing skills in historical essay-writing.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.

name: Problems in History: Transregional History
description: An introduction to the historical problems, the issues of interpretation, the primary sources, and the historical scholarship of transregional history, with an emphasis on developing skills in historical essay-writing.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.

name: Writing About History
description: Specialized courses focusing on history writing and research skills. Each class reflects the instructor's intellectual interests and is conducted as a discussion group. Limited to 18 students. Several short writing assignments and one longer project meeting the upper-division writing requirement.
prerequisite: HISTORY 12 or HISTORY 15A or HISTORY 15C or HISTORY 15D or HISTORY 16A or HISTORY 16B or HISTORY 16C or HISTORY 18A or HISTORY 21A or HISTORY 21B or HISTORY 21C or HISTORY 40A or HISTORY 40B or HISTORY 40C or HISTORY 60 or HISTORY 70A or HISTORY 70B or HISTORY 70C or HISTORY 70D or HISTORY 70E or HISTORY 70F
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.
restriction: History majors have first consideration for enrollment.

name: Topics in Environmental History
description: Explores the many historical interfaces between climate change, modes of production, and culture. Topics include the environmental history of warfare, imperialism, and famine in the nineteenth century and the history of environmental thought.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.

name: Europe in the Early Middle Ages
description: Survey of Europe between 300 A.D. and 900 A.D. Topics include the breakup of the Roman Empire, barbarian invasions, spread of Christianity, rise of Islam, the Carolingian Empire, and the Vikings.

name: Topics in Medieval Europe
description: Studies of the topics in Medieval Europe.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.

name: Topics in Early Modern Europe
description: Theme-based approach to the main social, political, and cultural developments in Europe between the fifteenth and eighteenth centuries.  Topics included Renaissance humanism, Reformation and Counter-Reformation, scientific revolution, court culture and nation building, interactions with non-European peoples, cities and commerce.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.

name: Topics in Modern European History
description: Course content changes with instructor. Topics include the Inquisition; science and religion in modern Europe; sex and society in modern Europe; French revolutions; culture in interwar Europe; the Holocaust; the fall of communism in Eastern Europe.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.

name: Europe: Twentieth Century
description: World War I and its impact on the modern world; rise of an international Communist movement; regimes created by Mussolini, Hitler, Stalin; World War II; the killing of Europe's Jews; Cold War and collapse of communism.

name: Modern Britain: 1700 to 1850
description: Examines the major developments in British politics, socioeconomic structure, and culture from 1700-1850. The development of the British nation-state and the fashioning of a national identity. Explores basic questions about British national identity.

name: Modern Britain: 1850 to 1930
description: Examines the social, economic, and political history of Britain from 1850-1930. Post-industrialism, urbanization, population and economic change, increased political participation by working classes and women, consolidation of the empire and the breakup of the United Kingdom.

name: Modern Britain: 1930 to Present
description: Explores Britain from the Second World War to resignation of Margaret Thatcher. Examines Britain's devolution from world power to member of the European Community; transition from a manufacturing to service-based economy; changing demographic and racial composition in light of decolonization.

name: The French Revolution: 1774-1815
description: Emphasis on social, economic, and cultural history of the French Revolution.

name: Revolution, Nation, and Modernity: France, 1789-1900
description: After 1789, France struggled to build a republic based on ideas of nationhood and citizenship with universal aspirations that could be exported to the rest of the world. Topics include empire, secularism vs. religion, gender relationships, birth of cinema.

name: War and Empire: France and the World in the 20th Century
description: Examines French experience of World War I, the defeat and occupation by Germany in World War II, the violent struggles that came with the loss of the French empire in the 1950s and 1960s, immigration, French responses to globalization.

name: History of Paris
description: The development of Paris from the beginnings through the present, with emphasis on the last three centuries. The city is examined from the political, social, ecological, and architectural points of view as well as through the perspective of urban planning.

name: Hitler and the Germans
description: Focuses on Hitler's rise to power and Nazi society. Examines Germany's defeat in World War I; the political and cultural experimentation of the 1920s; the causes of Hitler's success; and life in Germany under the Nazis.

name: Topics in Spanish History
description: Topics include Spain in the nineteenth century, the Spanish Civil War, and dictatorship and democracy in modern Spain.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.

name: Imperial Russia: 1689-1905
description: Political and social developments in Russia from 1689-1905.

name: Twentieth-Century Russia
description: Political and social developments in Twentieth-Century Russia.

name: The Era of World War I: 1900-1939
description: The era of World War I and its political, social and economic history.

name: The Era of World War II: 1933-45
description: The era of World War II and its political, social and economic history.

name: Topics in the History of Women in Europe
description: Studies in selected areas of history of European women. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.

name: Jewish History, Ancient to Early Modern Times
description: The history of the Jewish people from their origins in the ancient world to the 1700s. Social, religious, and intellectual life of Jewish communities in the Middle East, North Africa, and Europe.

name: Modern Jewish History
description: History of the Jews in Europe, the Middle East, North Africa, and the United States from the early-eighteenth century to recent times. Emancipation, assimilation, religious reform, antisemitism, Zionism, socialism, the Holocaust, and modern Israel are the major themes.

name: Topics in the Jewish History
description: Studies in selected areas of Jewish history. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.

name: History of Zoroastrianism
description: Reviews major trends in the history of Zoroastrianism.

name: Ancient Persia
description: Survey of the history of Persia in antiquity.

name: Medieval Persia
description: A survey of Persian history in the context of Late Antique and Medieval Islamic history.

name: Modern Iran
description: The history of Iran from the end of the Safavid Empire in the eighteenth century to the present.

name: Topics in Iranian History
description: Topics include the cultural, political, intellectual, social, and/or economic histories of Iran.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.

name: Israel and Palestine
description: Origins of Zionism in the nineteenth century, Arab-Jewish conflicts in Palestine, emergence of Palestinian nationalism, formation of the Israeli nation after 1948, and the development of the Palestinian movement. Focus on Palestinian and Israeli society and culture. Formerly History 132.

name: The Emergence of the Modern Middle East
description: Offers a survey of the history of the Middle East from the nineteenth century to the present time. Formerly History 133A.

name: Topics in Islamic History
description: The evolution of Islam as a religion within the social, political, and economic histories of various Muslim societies throughout its 14 centuries. Introduces major concepts, practices, and texts of Islam, and key historical events associated with them. Formerly History 131.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.

name: Topics in Middle Eastern History
description: Topics include the cultural, political, intellectual, social, and/or economic histories of one or many regions of the Middle East.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.

name: Africa: Societies and Cultures
description: Introduction to the variety of cultures, political organizations, social structures, and artistic expressions created by Africans over a broad time span. Indigenous development of African societies in distinct regions of the continent. Issues, themes, processes for understanding history of Africa.

name: Modern Africa
description: Explores the last 200 years of history in Africa, from the end of the Atlantic slave trade through colonization to independence.

name: Topics in the History of Africa
description: Studies in selected areas of African history. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.

name: Topics in South African History
description: Introduction to important historical events and processes in Southern Africa. Focuses on particular themes and explores how those themes change over time. Topics include: changing ideas about race, the development of class structures, identity formation, the role of gender.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.

name: History of the African Diaspora
description: Examines the causes and consequences of the multiple diasporas of African peoples since the sixteenth century in the Atlantic world, especially the Americas and Europe.

name: Crossing the World's Oceans: From Sail to Steam
description: Explores the basics of oceanography, the evolution of ships and sailing in the ancient Mediterranean world, the North Atlantic, Polynesia, the South China Sea, the Arab Indian Ocean, the global oceanic world, and the discovery of celestial and terrestrial navigation.

name: Maps from Prehistory to the Present
description: Examines how technology has assisted in creating visual representations of place, space, and time beginning in ancient Babylonia to the present day.

name: Topics in the History of Science and Technology
description: Studies in selected areas of science and technological history. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.

name: Language Origins: Evolution, Genetics, and the Brain
description: Examines how human language(s) may have originated. Studies pertinent techniques (reconstruction) and addresses related questions, including Is our language faculty inborn (i.e., genetically encoded)? Can brain imaging and population genetics research help to unlock this mystery of human evolution?.

name: Topics in the History of Medicine and Health Care
description: Studies in selected areas of Medicine and Health Care history. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.

name: Colonial America
description: Examines the interactions of various African, European, and Native American societies in North America, including social structures, politics, economics, and cultures.

name: Revolutionary America:  1740-1790
description: An exploration of why 13 continental colonies, whose commercial and cultural connections with Britain far exceed their interaction with one another, resisted imperial reform after 1763 to the point of war in 1775 and independence the following year.

name: California Dreaming: Conquest, Conflict, and Globalization in the Golden State
description: California as a case study of national trends and as a unique setting: its specific problems and culture. Major themes include: colonization, immigration, race relations, agricultural development, industrialization, urbanization, working class movements, social conflict, and political reform.

name: Topics in American Social and Economic History
description: Studies in selected areas of American social and economic history. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.

name: Topics in American Cultural and Intellectual History
description: Studies in selected areas of American cultural and intellectual history. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.

name: Sex in the U
description: Perspectives on sexual behavior in colonial and U.S. history to c. 1860. Mainstream and non-mainstream sexual practices, beliefs, identities. Asks why various ideas of sexual behavior developed and how they related to religious, racial, ethnic, political, cultural belief systems.

name: Topics in Women and Gender Relations in the United States
description: Studies in selected areas of women and gender relations in the United States. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.

name: Topics in Multicultural U
description: Examines the variety of cultural expressions through which the people who came to inhabit the United States historically signify their collective identities.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.

name: Topics in African American History
description: Studies in selected areas of African American history.  Topics addressed vary each quarter.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.

name: Chicana/Chicano History: Pre-Colonial to 1900
description: Examines social history of the southwest region from antiquity to 1900. Discusses major questions, theory and research methods pertinent to Chicanas/Chicanos. Themes include: indigenous empires, conquest, colonialism, social stratification, ideology, marriage, sexuality, industrial capitalism, accommodation and resistance.

name: Chicana/Chicano History: Twentieth Century
description: Examines social history of the Southwest with emphasis on Mexican-origin people. Discusses major questions, theory and research methods pertinent to Chicana/Chicano history. Themes explored include: immigration, xenophobia, class struggle, leadership, generational cohorts, unionization, education, barrioization, ethnicity, patriarchy, sexuality.

name: Latinas in the Twentieth Century U
description: Latinas in the U.S. from 1900 to present, offering a diversity of their cultures, regional histories, sexualities, generations, and classes.

name: Topics in Asian-American History
description: Introduction to important themes in the history of people of Asian ancestry in the United States from the nineteenth century to the present.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.

name: Asian American Labor
description: Explores history of Asian Americans and work from the nineteenth century to the present. Areas of study include migration, colonialism, family, social organization, and work culture.

name: Asian American and African American Relations
description: Addresses relationships of Asian American and African American communities in the United States. Topics include race, class, gender, labor, economic systems, political mobilization, community, civil rights, activism, cultural expression.

name: American Urban History
description: A study of urban communities in the United States, from colonial times to the present. Traces the impact of industrialization and urbanization on social and cultural life, and investigates the significance of urban life for U.S. democratic culture.

name: U
description: Examines post-World War II cultural, economic, and strategic patterns that have shaped U.S. relations with the world. Presents diverse perspectives on issues such as nationalism, anticommunism, secrecy and covert action, economic influences, the media's role, and race, gender, and class-related.

name: Sex and Conquest in Latin America
description: Competing ideas of masculinity and femininity, sexual violence, sexual identities, and gendered hierarchies informed how the Spanish engaged in military and religious domination of Mexican and Andean communities, as well as the forms of native resistance throughout colonial Latin America.

name: Twentieth-Century Mexico
description: Examines the history of contemporary Mexico beginning with the Mexican Revolution and concluding with the present administration. Social, economic, and political effects of the Revolution; formation of a "one-party democracy"; economic transformation of the nation; the present crisis.

name: Topics in Brazilian History
description: Studies in selected areas of Brazilian history. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.

name: World of Coffee
description: History of consumption and production of coffee over the centuries, and coffee's cultural, economic, social, political consequences. Coffee's social life as a drug, symbol of hospitality, religious rite, sociability and bourgeois lifestyle, commodity, source of livelihoods, imperial revenues, corporate profits.

name: Caribbean History: Colonization to Emancipation
description: Exploration of the history of the archipelago from pre-Columbian times to the end of slavery; examining the impact of European colonization, decimation of the indigenous populations, African slavery, resistance, and emancipation; the unity and diversity of experience in region.

name: Caribbean History: Emancipation to Independence
description: Post-emancipation and anti-colonial struggles ending with political independence for most of the region. Examines social, political, economic, cultural dimensions of post-emancipation period, including large-scale migration to Central America, the U.S., and Britain; the region's global cultural and political contribution.

name: Race and Empire in Colonial Latin America
description: Explores how native people of Latin America with enslaved and free African incorporated and defied Spanish and Portuguese colonization. Focuses on religious adaptions, resistance movements, legal systems, and the emergence of multicultural communities to explain how race shaped European empires.

name: War and Revolution in Colonial Latin America
description: Comparison of how Andeans resurrected the leaders of the Inca, a defeated indigenous empire, to contest the Spanish empire with how enslaved Africans, with their descendants and others, defeated Spanish colonial rule in what would become the Cuban nation.

name: U
description: Explores political, economic, social, and cultural ties that bind Latin America to the United States. Focuses on U.S. intervention and Latin American response from early nineteenth century to present day. Case studies include Mexico, Guatemala, Cuba, Chile, and Central America.

name: Gender, Race, and Nation in Latin America
description: Addresses the importance of gender and race to nation-making in Latin America during the 19th and 20th centuries (1810-1945). Considers how hierarchies between men and women shaped ideas about family, the state, and modernity.

name: Revolution and Reaction in Cold War Latin America
description: Explores Latin American experiences of revolutionary change and military dictatorship during the Cold War (1945-1990). Pays particular attention to the lives of women, peasants, workers, and the urban middle classes. Case studies include Guatemala, Cuba, Chile, Argentina, Nicaragua, and Mexico.

name: Cuban Society and Revolution
description: Explores the causes, development, and legacy of the 1959 Revolution. Themes include economic dependency, democracy, race, gender, culture, and the always volatile relations between Cuba and the United States.

name: Revolution in Latin America
description: Presents a comparative analysis of the causes, development, and consequences of selected revolutionary movements, focusing on outbreaks in Mexico, Bolivia, Cuba, Chile, Nicaragua, and Grenada.  Explores topics of state formation, economic nationalism, social justice, ethnicity, and role of international affairs.

name: Topics in Latin American History
description: Studies in selected areas of Latin American history.  Topics addressed vary each quarter.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.

name: Ancient India
description: Examines the visual and religious history of the region defined as "India" today, but necessarily encompassing modern Bangladesh and Pakistan.  Culminates with the supposed Golden Age of the Gupta empire and its far-reaching legacies.

name: Medieval India
description: Begins with the Gupta period's aesthetic legacies in South Asia's architecture, sculpture, and painting. Explores the dispersal of Islam throughout South Asia, including the Muslim communities of southern India.

name: Topics in the History of Asia
description: Topics include the cultural, political, economic, social, intellectual, and religious history of Asia.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.

name: Chinese History to 1800
description: A survey of the history of China to 1800.

name: Chinese History: 1800-1949
description: An examination of Chinese society and thought from the late-eighteenth century to the 1949 revolution. Focuses on the role of intellectuals; popular culture; women in Chinese society; developments in commerce and urban life; rebellion; foreign imperialism.

name: Topics in the History of China
description: Topics include the cultural, political, economic, social, intellectual, and religious history of China.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.

name: Age of the Samurai
description: Topics include the simultaneous elaboration of a civilian aristocratic tradition and the military ethos, the conflict between martial and economic values in the context of an expanding economy, and the development of Japan's indigenous religions, art, and literature.

name: Imperial Japan
description: Topics in the rise of modern Japan include the relationship between centralization and imperialism, democracy and fascism, industrialization and feminism in the context of the complex and competing forces that shaped Japan's experience in the modern world.

name: Postwar Japan
description: From the ashes of defeat to economic superpower, from poverty to material consumerism, from the ethic of diligence and fortitude to hedonism. Addresses what these changes have meant for ordinary people, as well as government policy and Japan's international position.

name: Topics in the History of Japan
description: Topics include the cultural, political, economic, social, intellectual and religious history of Japan.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.

name: Korean History to 1800
description: A general survey of the history of Korea to 1800. Focuses on internal sociopolitical development, major cultural trends, and foreign relations. Students are introduced to various interpretive approaches in the historiography.

name: Korean History: 1800-1945
description: An examination of Korean society and culture in tumultuous transition, focusing on some new challenges for the Choson Dynasty and its abortive reform effort, external imperialist pressures, and the Japanese colonial rule.

name: Korean History Since 1945
description: Topics include the national liberation, origins of conflict between two rival regimes, South Korea's emergence as a major player in the international political economy, some salient characteristics of the North Korean Marxist state, triumph of democracy, and prospect for reunification.

name: Topics in the History of Korea
description: Topics include the cultural, political, economic, social, intellectual, and religious history of Korea.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.

prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement
restriction: History majors only. Upper-division students only.

description: Students will sharpen their abilities to research, critically interpret, and present history by “doing history” beyond the formal classroom. Internships, which introduce students to the field of “public history,” include working as archivists, oral historians, project advisers, and exhibit curators.
restriction: Upper-division students only. History majors only.

description: Introduction to role of theory in historical writing, focusing on several major theorists, their relation to their setting, the structure of their thought, and its application to significant historical issues. (200A and 200B required for History Ph.D. students; 200C optional.).

description: Introduction to role of theory in historical writing, focusing on several major theorists, their relation to their setting, the structure of their thought, and its application to significant historical issues. (200A and 200B required for History Ph.D. students; 200C optional.).

name: Fourth Year Korean
description: Continued emphasis on comprehension, grammar, and proficiency in reading, composition, and conversation through intensive study and analysis of a variety of modern texts.

name: Fourth Year Korean
description: Continued emphasis on comprehension, grammar, and proficiency in reading, composition, and conversation through intensive study and analysis of a variety of modern texts.

name: Korean Literature: Advanced Texts
description: Designed for students with near-fluency in reading Korean. Readings include modern Korean literary works (poetry, prose, and drama) by important writers. Emphasis is on the interpretation of the texts and writings that interpret those texts in the original language.
repeatability: Unlimited as topics vary.

name: Topics in Korean Literature
description: Special topics through directed readings in Korean.  Paper required.
repeatability: May be taken for credit 3 times.

name: Independent Study
description: Investigation of special topics through directed reading in Korean. Paper required.
repeatability: May be taken for credit for 12 units.

name: General Chemistry
description: Atomic structure; general properties of the elements; covalent, ionic, and metallic bonding; intermolecular forces; mass relationships.  Course may be offered online.
prerequisite: MATH 5A or MATH 2A or PHYSICS 7C or CHEM 1P or placement via a score of 600 or higher on the SAT Mathematics Reasoning test, or a score of 27 or higher on the ACT Mathematics test, or a score of 700 or higher on the SAT Chemistry subject exam, or a score of 3 on the AP Chemistry exam,
restriction: Majors in the Schools of Physical Sciences, Biological Sciences, and Engineering, and majors in Nursing Science, Pharmaceutical Sciences, Public Health Sciences, and Undecided/Undeclared students have first consideration for enrollment.

name: General Chemistry
description: Properties of gases, liquids, solids; changes of state; properties of solutions; stoichiometry; thermochemistry; and thermodynamics.
prerequisite: CHEM 1A or ENGR 1A or CHEM H2A
restriction: Majors in the Schools of Physical Sciences, Biological Sciences, and Engineering, and majors in Nursing Science, Pharmaceutical Sciences, Public Health Sciences, and Undecided/Undeclared students have first consideration for enrollment.

name: General Chemistry
description: Equilibria, aqueous acid-base equilibria, solubility equilibria, oxidation reduction reactions, electrochemistry; kinetics; special topics.  Course may be offered online.
restriction: Majors in the Schools of Physical Sciences, Biological Sciences, and Engineering, and majors in Nursing Science, Pharmaceutical Sciences, Public Health Sciences, and Undecided/Undeclared students have first consideration for enrollment.

name: General Chemistry Laboratory
description: Training and experience in basic laboratory techniques through experiments related to lecture topics in Chemistry 1A.  Materials fee.

name: General Chemistry Laboratory

restriction: No credit for CHEM 1LC if taken after CHEM H2LB or CHEM M2LB. Majors in the Schools of Physical Sciences, Biological Sciences, and Engineering, and majors in Nursing Science, Pharmaceutical Sciences, Public Health Sciences, and Undecided/Undeclared students have first consideration for enrollment.

name: General Chemistry Laboratory
description: Training and experience in basic laboratory techniques. Chemical practice and principles illustrated through experiments related to lecture topics in CHEM 1A-B-C. Materials fee.
restriction: No credit for CHEM M2LA if taken after CHEM 1LD. Majors in the Schools of Physical Sciences, Biological Sciences, and Engineering, and majors in Nursing Science, Pharmaceutical Sciences, Public Health Sciences, and Undecided/Undeclared students have first consideration for enrollment.

name: Accelerated General Chemistry Lab
description: Lecture and experiments covering chemical concepts for accelerated students who do not plan to take organic chemistry. Properties of gases, liquids, solutions, and solids; chemical  equilibrium and chemical thermodynamics; atomic and molecular  structure; chemical kinetics; electrochemistry. Materials fee.
prerequisite: CHEM 1A or ENGR 1A or AP CHEM score of 3
restriction: Majors in the School of Engineering and Biomedical Computing majors have first consideration for enrollment.

name: Preparation for General Chemistry
description: Units of measurement, dimensional analysis, significant figures; elementary concepts of volume, mass, force, pressure, energy, density, temperature, heat, work; fundamentals of atomic and molecular structure; the mole concept, stoichiometry; properties of the states of matter; gas laws; solutions concentrations.  Course may be offered online.
restriction: Majors in the Schools of Physical Sciences, Biological Sciences, and Engineering, and majors in Biomedical Computing, Nursing Science, Pharmaceutical Sciences, Public Health Sciences, and Undecided/Undeclared students have first consideration for enrollment.

name: Honors General Chemistry
description: Covers the same material as CHEM 1A-CHEM 1B-CHEM M3C but in greater depth. Additional topics will also be included as time permits.
prerequisite: Placement via a score of 4 or 5 on the AP Chemistry exam, or a score of 700 or better on the SAT II in Chemistry
restriction: Campuswide Honors Program students only.

restriction: Chemistry majors only. No credit for CHEM M2LA if taken after CHEM 1LD.

description: Training and experience in basic laboratory techniques through experiments related to lecture topics in CHEM 1A-CHEM 1B-CHEM M3C. Materials fee.
restriction: CHEM 1LC may not be taken for credit if taken after CHEM H2LB or CHEM M2LB. Chemistry majors only.

name: Majors Quantitative Analytical Chemistry
description: Topics include equilibria, aqueous acid-base equilibria, solubility equilibria, oxidation reduction reactions, electrochemistry; and kinetics with a special emphasis on the statistical treatment of data and analytical methods of chemical analysis.
prerequisite: (CHEM 1B or CHEM H2B) and (CHEM M2LB or CHEM H2LB)
restriction: Chemistry majors only.

name: Majors Quantitative Analytical Chemistry Laboratory
description: Training and experience in analytical laboratory techniques through experiments related to lecture topics in CHEM M3C. Materials fee.
prerequisite: (CHEM 1B or CHEM H2B) and (CHEM M2LB or CHEM H2LB)
restriction: Chemistry majors only.

name: Scientific Computing Skills
description: Introduces students to the personal computing software used by chemists for managing and processing of data sets, plotting of graphs, symbolic and numerical manipulation of mathematical equations, and representing chemical reactions and chemical formulas.
corequisite: (CHEM 1C or CHEM H2C or CHEM M3C) and MATH 2D
restriction: Chemistry majors have first consideration for enrollment.

name: Chemistry Around Us
description: Addresses ways in which chemistry affects everyday life. Topics include pollution, global warming, water supply/demands, biodiesel fuels, foods we eat, natural/synthetic materials, common drugs, drug design. Learn and apply basic chemistry concepts. Use risk/benefit analysis for optimal solutions.

name: Organic Chemistry
description: Fundamental concepts relating to carbon compounds with emphasis on structural theory and the nature of chemical bonding, stereochemistry, reaction mechanisms, and stereoscopic, physical, and chemical properties of the principal classes of carbon compounds.
prerequisite: (CHEM 1C or CHEM H2C or CHEM M3C) and (CHEM 1LD or CHEM H2LC or CHEM M3LC)
restriction: Majors in the Schools of Physical Sciences, Biological Sciences, and Engineering, and majors in Nursing Science, Department of Pharmaceutical Sciences, Program in Public Health Sciences, and Undecided/Undeclared students have first consideration for enrollment.

name: Organic Chemistry
description: Fundamental concepts relating to carbon compounds with emphasis on structural theory and the nature of chemical bonding, stereochemistry, reaction mechanisms, and stereoscopic, physical, and chemical properties of the principal classes of carbon compounds.
prerequisite: CHEM 51A and (CHEM 1LD or CHEM M52LA or CHEM H52LA)
restriction: Majors in the Schools of Physical Sciences, Biological Sciences, and Engineering, and majors in Nursing Science, Pharmaceutical Sciences, Public Health Sciences, and Undecided/Undeclared students have first consideration for enrollment.

prerequisite: CHEM 51B and (CHEM 51LB or CHEM M52LB or CHEM H52LB)
restriction: Majors in the Schools of Physical Sciences, Biological Sciences, and Engineering, and majors in Nursing Science, Pharmaceutical Sciences, Public Health Sciences, and Undecided/Undeclared students have first consideration for enrollment.

description: Modern techniques of organic chemistry, using selected experiments to illustrate topics introduced in CHEM 51A-CHEM 51B-CHEM 51C.  Course may be offered online. Materials fee.

restriction: Majors in the Schools of Physical Sciences, Biological Sciences, and Engineering, and majors in Nursing Science, Pharmaceutical Sciences, Public Health Sciences, and Undecided/Undeclared students have first consideration for enrollment.

restriction: Majors in the Schools of Physical Sciences, Biological Sciences, and Engineering, and majors in Nursing Science, Pharmaceutical Sciences, Public Health Sciences, and Undecided/Undeclared students have first consideration for enrollment.

prerequisite: (CHEM 1C or CHEM H2C or CHEM M3C) and (CHEM 1LD or CHEM H2LC or CHEM M3LC)

prerequisite: CHEM H52A and (CHEM H52LA or CHEM M52LA)

prerequisite: (CHEM 1C or CHEM H2C or CHEM M3C) and (CHEM M3LC or CHEM H2LC or CHEM 1LD)
restriction: Campuswide Honors Program students only.

prerequisite: (CHEM 1C or CHEM H2C or CHEM M3C) and (CHEM H2LC or CHEM M3LC or CHEM 1LD)
restriction: Chemistry majors only.
